description:
This place is FANTASTIC. They have a couple of standout dishes that are amazing: the enoki mushroom salad, pea shoots (incredibly tender), boiled dumplings, noodles, and the sesame dessert balls. They also have very authentic and fresh tasting hot soy milk (sweet and unsweetened).

The service is also awesome and the place is clean with uncramped seating. I love this place!
author: Amy G.

description:
Service was awesome! So many stars only for the service.
Food:
I ordered the dumpling noodle soup with vegetarian dumplings. It was pretty bland. The dan dan noodles were good - we also replaced the pork with tofu.

Would recommend trying other dishes at this place.
author: Surbhi K.

description:
So yummy!

Ate here on a Friday right after work. About half the place was busy, so there is plenty of seating and the service is fast. Really great if you just want a variety of dumplings at reasonable prices with fast service.

Food:
- Dan Dan Noodles - I love the flavor of this, and the leftovers the next day were so good. It is a bit oily though.
- Chinese Broccoli - Great
- Pork Pot Stickers - Great
- Shanghai Soup Dumplings - Great
- Shanghai Pan-Fried Pork Buns - Just okay because the skins were a bit too thick and on the dry side.

Prices: Super Reasonable for this part of the city

Service: Fast

Atmosphere: Nothing fancy, but clean and well-lit.
author: Michelle B.

description:
3.5 stars. Solid place for a quick meal. I came here around 9.45pm and finished my meal in 25 minutes. 

I ordered the beef tendon to start (very authentic) and the chive and pork dumpling. The dumpling was pretty good but not exceptional. They suggested to use vinegar with chili sauce as dipping sauce. I prefer that dumpling house serves the dipping sauce for its clientele in general given that my version usually doesn't compare with the house version. 

$20 for both dishes. Good value. 

The service was fast but the server didn't give any opinion on the three appetizers that I was considering and just said they are all delicious. Don't look for guidance on the food here.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
Walking around Chinatown at dinnertime, it's clear which places are all the hype. House of Xian Dumplings may not be one of them but that doesn't mean you shouldn't give them a try.

At Xian Dumplings, you are still getting dumplings individually handmade and made to order. There are several fillings to choose from and one order can have as many as 12 dumplings. These dumplings are still 100% authentic and better than anything from the frozen section of your grocery store. We received great service and the prices were completely reasonable. My sister and I were able to enjoy our dinner without a long wait or feeling rushed to finish our meals.
author: Pari P.

description:
This place made me feel like a gambler. The dishes were pretty much a hit or miss. We ordered Boiled Corn and Chicken Dumplings (12) ($8.95), Green Onion Pancake ($6.50), Grilled Skewered Lamb ($8.95), and Dandan Noodle ($9.95).  

Hits:
- Green Onion Pancake: The pancake was very crispy on the outside and doughy in the inside. It seemed thicker than most green onion pancakes. There were not as many onion pieces as I thought there would be. Nevertheless, it was pretty good. 

- Dandan Noodle: These noodles tasted better than they looked. The dish was not salty and there was an adequate amount of meat. My friend would give this dish 5 stars. 

Misses:
- Grilled Skewered Lamb: It was extremely dry, under seasoned, and a little cold. My friend thought it was a disappointment and warned the waitress about this.

- Boiled Corn and Chicken Dumplings: Right when I took a bite, the corn pieces fell out. They were not mixed in well with the chicken. I think I would be better off buying chicken potstickers from Costco. 

If you want to use your credit card, you have to spend at least $15. Only one credit card is accepted per table. 

Since we only liked 50% of the dishes we ordered, we will probably not come back. In general, I recommend not getting dumplings at House of Xian Dumplings.. ironically.
author: Kristina M.

description:
Solid 3.5-4 stars. Decent prices on Chinese entrees and big portions for dumplings. Stopped by for lunch on the recommendation of a co-worker:
- Pan Fried dumplings - These were the bomb. The outside was thin and slightest bit bready, but inside you will find a moist, well-seasoned meatball. I usually don't love this style, but would get again in a heartbeat.
- XLB soup dumplings - really good. right thickness, broth is rich and not too anise-y
- Pea sprouts - solid and fresh, not too sweet.
- Beef and radish - I'd skip these, just kind of mushy and flat. Needs something to pop.
author: Billy D.

description:
We had a light Meal here one late afternoon a few days ago. Everything we ordered was good. Loved the Xiao Long bao (soup dumplings).

I was also surprised to see how many takeout orders this place gets. When we went in only two tables were occupied but our order didn't come as quickly (though still not late) due to the many takeout orders they were preparing.
author: Benjamin S.

description:
If you hate food, why would you open a restaurant?
Oh, that's right -- because you like tourist money.

Insider tip -- when you go into a xian restaurant and the hot chili pepper oil on the tables come from a bottle instead of from being rendered in the back room, when you can't smell a gust of peppery heat, leave. Turn around, don't look back.

Many of the positive reviews for this restaurant quote the lamb skewers and Shanghai soup dumplings. This is perplexing, as neither of these dishes are xian specialties. Which is fine -- good food of a region doesn't have to come from a restaurant of that region. But this was not good food.

The only reason to come here is if Chongqing Noodle and House of Nanjing next door have a 30 minute + wait and you have to sit down immediately or you will literally die.

Lamb skewers are supposed to be dry rubbed to extract moisture and then grilled over smoke to impart flavor and render the fat. These lamb skewers were cut so tiny that there was no possibility of juiciness, and were fried, not grilled - the laziest of possible preparations. The result is a greasy, salty, leftover-scraps-after-barbecuing style of lamb skewer that's tasty only by virtue of being seasoned fried meat. Why drive to SF Chinatown for that, though?

The dumplings are previously frozen, not fresh or made on premises. When you come from a Chinese family that cooks as often as mine does, the difference is immediate and obvious, from the dough to the shape, doneness, texture, and flavor of the filling.

It's not my intention to be a stickler for rules or a snobby gourmand, but this place is a parasite that continues to exist only by the grace of the overflowing success of the two restaurants next door (which are quality), and by being in Chinatown. Within a 200m radius of this restaurant, there are literally tens of restaurants where you can get a more authentic, better value, better flavor Chinese food fix.

Leave. Turn around. Don't look back.
author: Dan Z.

description:
I'd give this place 3.5 starts, but I'll round up because I'd go back for the Braised Beef Noodle Soup. Considering their name say is "house of dumpling", their dumplings were just okay... they could use more filling considering how thick the skin is. 

Also, DO NOT ORDER THE SHRIMP AND CHIVE DUMPLING (unless you want to get a dumpling full of chives. They use these TINY baby shrimps in it, and you'd  be lucky to find 2-3 of these baby shrimp in each dumpling. See photo for the minuscule shrimp I had to hunt in my dumpling.

TLDR;
- Get the braised beef noodle soup
- Chicken and corn dumplings were just okay, could use more filling. 
- STAY AWAY FROM SHRIMP AND CHIVE DUMPLING.
author: Jenna H.

description:
House of Xian Dumpling- very disappointing across the spectrum. From the service to the food, everything was abysmal.

Our waitress was slow and not attentive to us. It took her almost fifteen minutes just to take our order and it took a long time to get our bill too. Waters were never refilled as well.

We ordered the pork & vegetable dumplings, house special chow mein and a basket of the xiaolongbao. Among the three dishes, only the chow mein was edible. Even though it was edible, it was still a bit too greasy for me. The pork & vegetable dumplings were bland and you could tell from the texture that they were frozen, from a bag. I don't think they are made fresh daily. The xiaolongbao was the most disappointing though. We ate these right away immediately but there was no soup broth inside the dumplings. The dough texture was also beyond chewy too. 

This restaurant was just not very good. There are much better Chinese restaurants to try in the Chinatown area.
author: Philip M.

description: Very slow service. Ordered take out and waited 45 mins even though there were no customers. People in the kitchen just didn't feel like cooking apparently.
author: Anna M.

description:
Eh nothing too flashy here... We ordered the chasiu chow mein, egg flower soup, and pork Xiao long bao. 

Chow mein was too greasy!! Didn't have any spectacular flavor to it and the chasiu wasn't sweet at all. Barely noticed it was there.

Xiao long bao like others mentioned has a thick skin which I actually prefer! However that is only because you want to ensure all the soup stays in. BUT THERE WASNT ANY SOUP INSIDE!!! This is a travesty. What Xiao long bao doesn't have soup inside? At least the meat tasted good, but no soup = a deal breaker.

Lastly, the egg flower soup came after the two entrees???? It should be the first thing served... Anyway, oddly it had a lot of cabbage which Ive never had in my soups before. It also had really little mushroom. This was basically poached eggs and cabbage in a clear broth. I knew I shouldn't have let my partner choose the restaurant .
author: Edmund L.

description:
3.5 stars is an accurate rating for this place. My husband, who is from Xi'an, was craving food from his hometown. We've been to Terra Cotta Warrior in the Sunset before and liked it, but he wanted to try something new.

We came with low-ish expectations given the mixed reviews, and everything was just fine but ultimately forgettable. We ordered the dan dan noodles, wonton in chili oil, lotus root salad, green onion pancakes, and lamb skewers -- and it was all OK, if not a bit bland. The dan dan noodles were probably the best dish, but I've had still had better elsewhere.

The lamb skewers needed twice the amount of spices. The green onion pancakes tasted frozen and re-heated, the chili oil for the wontons didn't pack much flavor, etc. Sense a theme here? 

Overall, it's fine for a quick bite if you're hungry in Chinatown, but it's not worth the trek. Terra Cotta Warrior still wins my vote.
author: Valerie L.

description:
They're service is not the best, but the food is pretty good. I came here a few times with my 3 other coworkers and we always get the braised beef noodle soup, house special fried rice, shanghai soup dumpling to share and we always get a different 4th item to try. We've tried the corn and chicken dumpling, which we didn't really enjoy and the chicken chow mein, which is OK but not amazing. 

I would definitely recommend the braised beef noodle soup, house special fried rice and shanghai soup dumpling. The braised beef noodle soup is a little spicy, but manageable and the meat is very tender. I usually don't get house special fried rice at other chinese restaurants, but I did enjoy it here - it was very flavorful and different from other house special fried rice dishes I've had elsewhere. I shanghai soup dumpling isn't the best I've had, but it's definitely not bad and does have some soup in there.
author: Bailey L.

description:
After half a year, I came back here last night, and left VERY, VERY disappointed. 

For a place that proclaims "dumpling" in their name, you should have some respect for the dumplings served.

These were the tiniest dumplings I have ever eaten. I've eaten a lot of dumplings. I was shocked when they came out. Might as well have been pizza pockets. 

What a freaking downgrade. And for $10?!? 

Stop trying to cut down costs by downsizing & ripping off your new customers / disappointing your recurring ones.
author: Vickie Z.

description:
Tried: the soup dumplings, beef noodle soup, and dandan noodles. 

This tiny restaurant was packed with people when I came, and I'm not sure why since the food is really nothing special. The noodles are bland and flavorless, and the soup dumplings don't even have any soup in them (?!). Service was alright. Skip this place and eat at one of the neighboring restaurants!
author: Ming Y.

description:
I'm really sad right now... because I just ran out of dumplings! I don't get what some of the other reviews are talking about because these dumplings are sooo good. We got the boiled cabbage and chicken dumplings to go and now I regret not getting more... 

We were around the area and wanted a quick bite, so we decided to drop in here cause it seemed comfortable and bright. The waiters greeted us well and we sat down. Although we changed our minds to just get something to go, they were kind to let us still sit there and serve us water right away. They also seemed appreciative of our business as we left. 

Can't go wrong with hand made dumplings and the hand pulled noodles we saw other tables get looked really good as well. I think this place is overshadowed by some of the fancier places around them and some bad reviews may make some people hesitant to try it. Maybe stick to what they're named after..? For a tourist area like that, it's good pricing too. 

Thank you for the good dumplings and friendly service. We'll be back when we're around there again. :)
author: Sung L.

description:
I am so impressed with the soupy dumplings. They are a little bit of heaven. They have a good deal of soup in them and steamed to perfection. The Kung Pao Chicken was also very good, nice and spicy with very fresh ingredients. I'm so happy that I wondered into this place, they had me with the soupy dumplings. The service was very fast and friendly!

Now my 10th time here at the food is amazing! What a great spot for dumplings steaming hot and outrageously delicious!

Thanks for the great food that I don't get at home in Chicago.
author: Blake J.

description: All dishes I ordered were poorly cooked. Dumplings are broken-skinned. The filling supposed to have pork and shrimp, but I can barely taste any. The so called hand-pulled noodle was dead in pieces and very starchy. The cabbage (cold dish) was 1. Poorly cut, uneven pieces... 2. tasted sweeter than a desert, fully of sugar. Really disappointed :(
author: Fiona J.

description:
Decent little dumpling place in Chinatown. Great prices, quick service.

My favorite dish here was actually their take on Dan Dan noodles, but their dumplings are pretty good.

This place is PACKED at noon, but a half hour earlier or later and you should be golden.
author: Jimmy S.

description:
I came here on a weekday evening with a friend since we were feeling a bit hungry and didn't feel like splurging that day. When we walked in, the restaurant was roughly at a quarter capacity. We took a seat and started looking at the menu. I went straight to the noodle soup page and found the Hot Pickled Mustard Tuber & Shredded Pork Noodle Soup. I ordered it and then we waited for our dishes. 

A couple minutes later, our dishes arrived and I dug in. The noodles were pretty good and I did appreciate the fact that the noodles were hand-pulled. However, the soup was relatively bland and wasn't as sour as I hoped it would be. The shredded pork and the vegetables were alright and I didn't really have much to say about them. 

Overall, this dish was alright but not as good as I had expected. Perhaps I just ordered a noodle dish that they weren't really known for. With the benefit of hindsight, perhaps I should have ordered the House Spicy Chicken Noodle Soup or one of the many other noodle dishes on the menu. I would recommend coming here if you want cheap food since their prices are pretty reasonable (hopefully your dish won't be a dud and mine was a fluke).
author: Nelson X.

description:
I wish I could give them a better review, but I went here last night with a couple of other people and our order took over one hour to come out. 

I ordered the Spicy Beef Soup, the other two ordered Braised Beef Soup and Shrimp Chow Mein, and together we ordered dumplings and a green onion pancake. 

The dumplings were delicious. They were juicy and packed with flavor. Unfortunately the green onion pancake was over cooked and came out very crispy and doughy. The Spicy Beef Soup was actually quite tasty with the broth and beef being the highlights. 

I believe that take-out orders took priority over people seated in their restaurant the day we were there. We noticed delivery person after delivery person come and go as we waited super long for our own food. With that being said, If they want to prioritize take-out, maybe they should think about being a take-out ONLY place.
author: Kevin B.

description:
My husband and I were visiting San Francisco from New Orleans, where there is a large Vietnamese population. We were excited to get to try Chinese food in Chinatown- specifically soup dumplings. It took us a while to get to House of Xian so by the time we were seated, we were starving.

My husband ordered us the soup dumplings, ordered DanDan noodles for himself, and the braised beef noodle soup for me.  It was so delicious we made a point to come back the day we left and have the exact meal again for lunch.
author: Liz V.

description:
Portion is bigger than I expected, I had to ask for a to go box.  
I ordered a beef noodle soup and a red oil frying hand dumplings, food came to table quickly but It was around 1pm when I had my lunch so the restaurant wasn't too crowded.
author: Es L.

description:
I read and re-read the Yelp reviews for Chinese food in my area in the middle of Chinatown before choosing this one. I chose wrong.
Perhaps the dumplings are the thing to stick with here (hence the name?), as my soup dumplings were the best part. My Kung pao chicken was so salty I had to pick around the chicken and just eat the veggies and peanuts. The sauce wasn't salty, but the chicken itself was like a salt lick. 
Salt and pepper wings were bland as was the house fried rice. I read the reviews for Sam Wo's wings, and I hoped these would be close. I added two packets of sriracha to the rice to liven it up, but it was still disappointing.
Three stars? The staff was super friendly, and the dining room clean and inviting. And my Tsing Tao was perfect.
author: Julie S.

description:
I ate at this place when they first opened.  It was very good.  Subsequently, I have eaten here a couple of other times.  Specific things on the menu are worth trying, while others should be avoided.

I recommend any of their noodles, especially the beef soup noodles.

All the pork dumplings I have tried have been very good, but I suggest you avoid anything with shrimp filling at all costs.  There is nothing noticeable in the way of shrimp inside, just a wispy smear (skid-marks) of shrimp paste.  But then again, being so far from the sea, Xi'an isn't known for shrimp dumplings, mutton, yes, but not shrimp.

Reasonably priced.  The service is okay.

My only other issue with this place -- other than the shrimp dumplings -- is on one occasion the dumplings had been boiled too long and were disintegrating.  Couldn't eat them.
author: Jaime C.

description:
Is the place good? It's decent. A friend of mine thinks it's really good and he's a world traveler. So the bro and I came here today to take a break from work in Oakland. He took me here to try it. 

Well, let's say, under staff. It seems they get a lot of phone orders or online orders. Plus, the regular traffic. The waitress was very kind to explain each dishes I asked. 
 
If you're a type of customer that expects your waitress to come and ask how you're doing and always check up on you, this isn't the place for you. This isn't a restaurant with ambiance or anything fancy. You come here strictly for the food. If you want something, you ask for it. 

We ordered: 

Beef Pancake - it was okay. Nothing to rave about. Didn't really taste the beef. 

Shanghai Dumping - it was good. It could use a bit more meat in it. 

Dan Dan Noodles - the bro ordered it, nothing jumped out that makes me want to order it for myself. 

Braised Beef Noodle Soup - it was good. Spice was right and the beef was very tender. The noodles were perfectly cooked. 

Like I mentioned, this place is okay, if in the area, I might go back to try other dishes on the menu.
author: ARIeL P.

description: Authentic!  We ordered the braised beef noodle soup and chive and pork dumplings to split as we weren't too hungry from snacking at nearby Boba guys.  The broth tasted very savory and was balanced in saltiness, while the hand pulled noodles had a full and hearty texture.  Would definitely want to come again!
author: David D.

description:
Got their Chili Oil Wontons, Boiled Chives & Shrimp Dumplings and Shanghai Pan-Fried Pork Buns.  

Chili Oil Wontons 
(5+ really delightful)

Boiled Chives & Shrimp Dumplings 
(Solid 4.5, definitely up to a 5 when you use the soy/vinegar sauce. Chive forward! YUM) 

Shanghai Pan-Fried Pork Buns.  
(Meh, 3 nothing wrong but not going to order it again from here. I know it's a bun but the skin is WAY too thick. Either that or they need to fill it with more 'stuff.')

Postmates delivery fee was a bit pricey, but it looks like you can get it from here for $3 dollars less. Not going to rate them down for that.

Looking forward to trying the lamb skewers, XLB, and pea sprouts.
author: Valerie F.

description: Got the pork & cabbage, pork & chives, xlbs, pea sprouts, lotus salad, and green onion pancakes. The pork and chives were hands down the best. Probably one of the best dumplings I've had in SF. Very flavorful right amount of chive to meat ratio. Pork and cabbage was a bit more bland, I wanted some more cabbage. Xlbs were made well, good amount of soup and flavor but the stuffing was a bit too dense for me. Pea sprouts needed some garlic and flavoring. Lotus salad was terrible. And the green onion pancake was just a fried lump of dough.
author: Beryl Y.

description:
I've passed by House Of Xian Dumpling many times and unlike like its neighbors, House of Nanking & Chong Qing Xiao Mian, it hardly gets any love meaning that its almost empty while there are people waiting outside House of Nanking & Chong Qing Xiao Mian for a table to open up. I like to subject myself to low quality places and that it is open late and it has an online ordering app, all of which made me check it out.

During my first visit I decided to get the Braised Beef Noodle Soup ($9.95) to-go. When I reached after about 20 minutes they handed me the wrong order and asked me to pay. Anyway after clearing that up with the confused hostess I had to wait another 15 minutes and I was on my way.

The broth of the beef noodle soup was average. The beef scant and chewy, but the best feedback is for the noodles. The menu says that these are hand pulled noodles. The question I want to ask is - When were these pulled. A day ago? A week ago? And then they were left to sit out and dehydrate? Man I did not know that having dry, chewy, doughy noodles was now a thing. Bad that's all that I can say.

I didn't learn my lesson. I thought maybe I should have got the dumplings as that's what their name says and that's what would be good. So I was back to get the Dumpling Noodle Soup ($9.95). This time my order was ready after 20 minutes of ordering and I was on my way. The story repeats itself. I have to blame myself for this. There was no reason to get the noodles again knowing how terrible they were but that's me. I got the corn and chicken dumpling which I can swear was straight out of a bag of frozen dumplings that had not even been thawed correctly. What a shame.

Crowds don't like. Go see for yourself. Chong Qing Xiao Mian & House of Nanking will be packed, but there will hardly be two tables occupied in House Of Xian Dumpling. Now you know why.
author: Ahmad J.

description:
Small place that seats 36.  Food is good and portions are generous. 

Easy to get in and out
author: Steph T.

description: We had a blast here. The food was really good, we almost licked our plates clean! The food came out really fast and the service was great! Highly recommend.
author: Tyler S.

description: Actually surprisingly decent dumplings for being in this area. We tried the cabbage and pork dumplings.I told my coworker I think we found a new lunch spot. Can't wait to try more dishes to update my review :)
author: Tasha L.

description:
I was craving soup dumplings and wanted to give this place a shot but it was disappointing. Not sure if their soup dumplings are even homemade because they tasted like frozen ones. There wasn't much juice and the skin was thick. The dumplings looked too uniform to be homemade too..

Their handpulled (are they handpulled?) beef noodle soup was ok. The noodles were really thick and kinda hard. In my 26 years of eating noodles I've never had ones like these... hmm... The broth wasn't traditional and it tasted kinda sour for some reason, but it wasn't awful. I guess if you're looking for not AWFUL, then come here. 

Okay okay! Their one redeeming factor was their pan fried pork buns!! Perfectly steamed then fried on the outside and soft with a bit of juice and plump meat on the inside. This was good. Get this.
author: Sally L.

description:
I ordered Beijing buns, soy milk, Fandango noodle and diaolongbao. None of them are good and kinda pricy considering the amount and quality. 
Don't order from them.
author: Wen W.

description:
I like the pot stickers! Pretty tasty. They come with a sauce that I really like, too.

Will be re-ordering the veggie pot stickers from here :)
author: Meghan J.

description:
This is a fine place for Chinese dumplings and noodles, yet they clearly don't understand how to balance price with size!!
PS: THEY SEEMS TO SOMEHOW FORCE ADDED TIPS INTO YOUR RECEIPT! As a costumer, you should be able to choose the amount of tip given!!!
author: Zhang J.

description: Came here for dumplings because I had been craving dumplings, since there was no DTF around we settled here. We ordered soup dumpling, 2 orders of wonton in chili oil and chicken fried rice. Everything taste good. I didn't have any complaint, service was a bit slow and the water for some reason looked a funny color. Satisfied my craving so that was that haha.
author: Linh N.

description:
I came here for a late Sunday lunch and we were seated within 10 minutes. 
 
Split the beef tendon noodle soup, chili wonton, fried buns, pork, chive and shrimp dumplings. Food was quite good and the dumplings here are amazing. Surprisingly, probably the best dumplings I've had in SF. 

Our group accidentally double tipped because the receipt is misleading and didn't see any signs for mandatory gratuity. Double check your receipts!
author: Edward W.

description:
Best soup dumpling! This only includes soup dumplings in Manhattan, SF and Toronto.
The point is: the filling is rich and the wrap is so thin! I absolutely fall in love with the soup dumpling. 
Lamb skewers are great, too. Small dishes are authentic. Chive dumplings are good with pork and ok with shrimp.
author: Isabelle L.

description:
Meh, it's a good option within walking distance from the office whenever my coworkers and I are craving dumplings.  We heard about this place from others in the office and it's definitely a change of pace from our usual soup, sandwich, and salad fare.  Aside from their XLBs, they have a nice selection of boiled dumplings too from pork to chicken to even beef, fish and lamb.  I personally prefer their dumplings over their XLBs.  Not sure if they were steamed for too long but no soup in each bun + the skin was super doughy and tough, not the best combo.  

If you are not big on dumplings, they also have some pretty tasty hand pulled noodles.  They have some tough competition when it comes to Noodles a few doors down but not bad.  The 2 of us ordered a noodle soup, 1 dumpling, and 1 XLB and it was plenty of food w/ some leftovers.  

The restaurant is pretty small in itself and does fill up quick during lunch so definitely come early before the lunch crowd.  The lady server we had was very knowledgeable, explained some of the items on the menu and offered some recommendations.  However, the owner lady that came around later on was not as friendly.  She was rushing several tables to finish and the table next us was only half way done with their meal when she asked if they needed a box.  We saw a WTF look on their faces but quickly looked away as I'm sure it was awkward and uncomfortable for them.  Thank goodness my table was done and getting ready to pay but I'm sure it's not a great feeling to feel so rushed through lunch.
author: Janetto L.

description:
House of Xian is quickly becoming my go-to for delicious #dumps and #noodz in the city!

I love recommending this place to people looking for delicious, no-frills Chinese food. The hand pulled noodles are chewy and endless, just the way they should be - I like the regular kind more than the thick kind, but they're both delicious. Of course get the beef noodle soup. I also really like their Dan Dan Mien - the serving is huge! And of course, their dumplings (pork and cabbage is the real deal) are just steamed goodness. I have to say, the Yelp reviews judging this place solely by their soup dumplings should be ignored. You can't judge a place that serves Xian cuisine by their soup dumplings (xiao long bao) - leave that for the Shanghainese places. I think their xiao long bao is okay, but their normal steamed dumplings are where it's at.

I'm perfectly okay with people going to House of Nanking next door instead because that means more dumplings and noodles for me!
author: Alyssa T.

description: We tried the cabbage pork dumplings, noodle soup with chive shrimp dumplings, a vegetarian noodle soup and a plate of stir fried snow pea tips.  We thought the food was a little better than average but not memorable.  The service was attentive, and the place was tidy.
author: Frank L.

description:
I ate at House of Xian dumpling during a quick weekend trip up to the bay area. Before leaving, we did a quick swing through San Francisco's Chinatown district. It was hard choosing a place to eat because there were so many restaurants in the community! 

But after doing a quick walkaround, and seeing a good crowd at this location, we decided to eat here. I'm a big fan of both soup dumplings and Chinese beef noodle soup. The soup dumplings were great---but I will never forget the noodle soup! It was the best noodle soup I've ever had. The noodles were tender yet firm, and the broth was well balanced and slightly sweet. Not too oily, but insanely flavorful. The beef was also tender, soft, and melt in your mouth. 

I'm looking forward to coming back here once I make another trip up to the bay.
author: Melissa C.

description: spicy beef noodle soup and spicy tendons were good rest of stuff was meh. xiao long bao was not fresh and probably came from the freezer. the shanghai pan fried dumplings were dry, the boiled chive and pork dumplings tasted like the ones from 99 ranch. I didnt get the onion pancake but that looked mediocre as well. I would only come here for the spicy beef and tendon soup and the tendons
author: Robert Y.

description: Love that this place has veggie and chicken dumplings. I usually order the cabbage/corn dumplings and veggie noodles when I'm feeling super carby or have a real asian food craving. I normally do pickup and the service is fast, easy, and friendly! Highly recommend. Portions are large so one appetizer and one entree is plenty for two people.
author: Cindy B.

description: Delicious and friendly service. We ordered the dandan noodles and pork dumplings with cabbage. Both delicious!
author: Lori S.

description:
Honestly a bit of a letdown given the slow service and mediocre food.

I ordered a braised beef noodles and an order of shrimp, chive, and seafood dumplings. The dumplings arrived long before the noodles. Unfortunately they were almost entire chives with barely any meat/seafood which also meant that it was relatively bland. The beef noodles arrived quite a bit later and it was definitely more flavorful but strangely sweet for braised beef noodles. Thankfully they had a bit more kick which made for a good soup to dunk what few dumplings we had left just so they could have a bit more seasoning.

The disappointing food combined with the really suboptimal way the food comes out makes this place a pass for me.
author: Jason W.

description: My work orders from here on Postdates at least once a month for our happy hours. Over $300 in dumplings. Great quality and delicious options, its always a crown favorite. The reason for 4 stars is most times the order has something missing or is inaccurate. I don't know if that is on this side or the post mates side because I think they are supposed to check the orders? Anyways, we get a few orders of each of the dumplings and potstickers and spring rolls.
author: Courtney S.

description: Go, get dumplings, enjoy. This place rocked. A group of 6 of us all came and ordered a number of things, we ordered more of everything. The dumplings were fantastic and the noodles seemed to be cooked perfectly. They had everything on the menu you would need to feed even picky eaters or the adventurous.
author: Conor S.

description:
Terrible terrible experience! If I can give negative stars I definitely will! 

Now I am sitting in this restaurant waiting for my noodle for more than one hour and ask the waiter for 3 times why I still don't get my dish. However, those Caucasian customers get their dish pretty efficient. Come on! I am an Asian and the owner and waiters are all Asians! Why they treat another Asians differently?!
author: Anna Y.

description: We ordered soup dumplings, beef and onion dumplings, green onion pancake, salt and pepper tofu, dumplings in chili oil, bok choy, shredded potato and chili oil and a few other things. It was all so amazing. The service was fantastic and everyone was so polite.
author: Andie K.

description: Love this small restaurant that serves up a delicious assortment of dumplings. My favorites are the pork soup dumplings (be careful or you'll splash soup on your clothes) and the pork & cabbage dumplings (I'm a pork fan)!  The green onion pancake is also recommended (ask for a side of sweet & sour sauce). Get here early since it gets crowded during the lunch hour. Prices are very reasonable and you'll leave a satisfied customer!
author: Susan N.

description: Enjoyed a great Beef Noodle Soup. I just wished they would give a full glass of wine.. Not 1/2 glass. Good way to lose a customer.
author: Frank H.

description:
Met up with my friends for lunch. Pretty empty at 11, crowds rolled in after 12. It's a small place of maybe 10 tables. They have a pretty big menu from appetizers to noodles to rice to, of course, dumplings. 

We ordered the Braised beef noodle soup, cabbage and pork dumplings, corn and chicken dumplings, XLBs, and Grilled chicken skewers. Dumplings are ok.. They literally were just boiled dumplings with filling. The filling lacked flavor as well. I thought they'd have some special sauce provided but no... it's just hot/soy sauce on the table. The XLBs lacked the soup inside. There was some but I expect it bursting out. The skewers were pretty good. I'm not a big fan of the rub though. The most notable dish was the braised beef noodle soup. It had really good flavor. The beef was tender and noodles were nice and chewy. With the extra soup leftover, I used it to drench the plain dumplings; made the taste so much better.

If you are ordering dumplings, I recommend getting the braised beef noodle soup as a complement.
author: Benita M.

description:
Come get the beef noodle soup. I know it's a dumpling place, yadi yadi ya. Just get that. If you like beef tendon, definitely go for that version. The tendons were so soft and so easy to chew. The noodles were also pretty solid themselves (I got the regular ones). The soup is where it shines though. It has a little bit of spice (not too much to consider it a spicy dish) and really gives it that flavor.

I got the deep fried buns, stay away. Ordered 6 for group of 3, there were still 3 remaining when we left.
author: Victor D.

description:
We came here hungry after a full day of roaming around Fisherman's Wharf and Palace of Fine Arts. Since the place was called House of Xian Dumpling, I figured that I should order dumplings to see if the restaurant had been named appropriately lol. My friends who have been here said the noodles are a must-try, so I decided to get the dumpling noodle soup - best of both worlds.

- Dumplings: wrapper was a bit too thick and doughy for my liking. Actually a couple of my other friends thought that the dumplings back home were better too.
- Noodles: hand-pulled noodles were decent. I asked to have it spicy to clear up my sinuses too lol. It was quite a big bowl, and I definitely could have gotten away with just a little more than half to be satisfied.

The dumplings were sub-par, and though the noodles were decent, it couldn't make up for the dumplings. Hoping to find a better dumpling/noodle place out there.
author: Joanna C.

description:
A few years ago, a friend who works in the area told me about this neighborhood spot that borders North Beach, Jackson Square, and Chinatown.  He enjoyed their dumplings and noodles, but, being a bit of a, tsk, tsk, dumpling snob, I never found the time to try it.
Recently, another friend surprised me by inviting me here for a weekday lunch.  
Arriving around 1 pm, there were four or five occupied tables as we were seated on a wall side table.  My friend studied the menu and ordered the following, all shared:

1) House special sizzling rice (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=BtPr2KvZsYXutCwKVgBtYA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Do not advise ordering this unless you are a fan of the place a few doors over or just enjoy anything fried.

2) Celery and shrimp dumpling (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=W4F8BhJQCqb_VlZ5e7PqlQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Never heard of this combination but it works.  The celery flavor wasn't overwhelming and no fishiness from the shrimp.

3) Xiao Lung Bao (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=I8o17MDcDsQiLu-TOeEE9Q&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Very good version as the skin was thin, yet held the integrity of the fillings well.  Good soup content, but definitely eat them while hot.

4) Braised beef noodle soup (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=Bn8ZSjOC6xITHdgetU7igA&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - Pretty good rendition as the broth flavor was clean and the meat pieces had a good mix of lean and tendon.  The noodles are on the wider side which lends me to believe that they are pulled in house.

5) Sliced lotus root salad - Good change from the above with a pleasantly seasoned marinade while the lotus was shredded into easy to eat pieces.  My friend ate most of this while I mostly finished the noodle soup.

Service was efficient but pretty vanilla, empty plates removed and teapot checked from time to time.  The noise level is pretty good as we could have a decent conversation without having to raise our voices. 
Besides the above mentioned restaurant, there are a number of noodle places on Kearny Street now.  The menu here has more options especially if you are in the mood for dumplings.
Good spot for a casual meal and will be back.
author: Mike C.

description: First time dined at this place with a coworker for lunch and I have to say their food is pretty good! Had dumplings and Xiao Long Bao and a bowl of noodle, great flavor and good size, good pricing too! The place is relatively small so waiting outside for a table is mostly the case but not too long of a wait.
author: Junia p.

description:
We were in San Francisco and wanted to grab a quick lunch. Located in Chinatown right on Kearny its is easy to find and there is plenty of parking in the Portsmouth's parking lot. House of Xian dumpling is a small place and when we arrived there was only a couple of customers.  We ordered a little of everything, I'll list from worst to best. 

Salty soy milk 1 star normal Chinese breakfast item was horrible after a couple of tried sips we asked the server to take it away. Do you want it to go, we said it was aweful. He did not offer or take it off the bill. 

XLBs. 2 stars no soup in the dumplings at all we had to ask fir some ginger to put in the sauce.

Pork and Cabbage dumplings 2 stars thick skinned I have frozen market dumplings that are better

Shau Bing You Tau 3 stars decent 

Green Onion Pancakes 3 stars

Shredded Potato 3 stars

Garlic Stir Fried pea greens 3 stars

Pan Fried San Chian Pao 4 stars 

Beef tendon 4 stars

Beef Noodle soup 4 stars the best item of the meal 

Service was just ok. $82 before tip.
author: George F.

description:
Excellent Chinese comfort food. The chow mein was so warm and filling on a cold evening out in Chinatown. I loved the flavor of the xiao long bao (soup dumplings), although they weren't as soupy as I am normally used to. 

I would probably order the beef and tofu again after knowing the taste, but I would recommend a side of white rice! Their other chicken dishes looked very delicious. The space inside is small, so come with a small party or bring a date!
author: Juliana P.

description:
Anytime I'm in San Francisco or any other place with a decent China town, I go searching for those darn knife cut noodles! While their noodles weren't quite what I was looking for, they were still excellent! I was there with a very large group of people and they accommodated our group size as and handled our crazy ordering beautifully. The dan dan noodles were delicious as was the lotus root salad. If you've not had lotus root, you must give it a try. Many people in my group were also happy with the soup dumplings and some of the beef dishes. I did not like the chicken dumplings. 

If you're looking for a great, almost authentic taste of China, stop in and enjoy some food at House of Xian!
author: Feed M.

description:
The house chicken hand pulled noodles and the xiaolongbao here: 


I've also had the chicken and corn dumplings - not my favorite but not bad.

Chives and pork dumplings are also great but I don't like to eat pork a lot so I just stick to one type of pork dumpling - Xiaolongbao.

Very easy to miss this spot though as it's a very small, hole-in-the-wall restaurant in Kearny.
author: Michelle K.

description: Delicious food and a great price. I would definitely eat there again. My family ordered several items and all of them were delicious. Pot stickers, dumplings, sweet and sour chicken,  chicken skewers and briased beef noodle soup. I highly recommend you try them.
author: Selena V.

description:
I tried the "Braised Beef and Beef Tendon Noodle soup" the soup had a nice spicey flavor and the noodles were just fine, but I noticed it had very little meat? I had to look for the beef tendon and it was only a tiny piece , most places put a little more meat in the soup.

for $9.99 it should have some more meat, it was mostly soup not much noodles either.

so I guess it was OK, but Ive had better.

the service was excellent, they accept credit cards on $15 or more order, thats good.

I would still come back to try more dishes to get a better review, it's actually a pretty nice restaurant.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: The best Chinese food in all of Chinatown!  Great family.  Nice people and amazing food!
author: Donald K.

description:
I always love a good dumpling, so the food here hit the spot, but as an avid dumpling and noodle fan, it fell short of expectations given how good food generally is in SF's Chinatown.

The dumpling meat was a bit bland and the wrappers were a bit too dense and mealy.

We ordered Xiao long bao soup dumplings which were tiny, and had a thick skin. There was soup inside each bite so they passed my test but most people would prefer a more delicate springy skin and a larger dumpling size.

The pan fried dumplings (Shen jiang bao) were very disappointing. Not juicy inside at all but a bit dry and steamed bread outer layer was mealy and dense like when I try to make my own dough at home. Perhaps there is no comparison to Tasty Noodle House in Alhambra which hits it out of the park.

The beef stewed noodle soup was delicious (tender meat slices and nice flavorful broth) but it was a bit untraditional as it was slightly sweet and didn't have any star anise flavor. I did love that we could get thin or thick/flat hand pulled noodles.

Prices were great ($7.95 for the dumplings, $8.95 for the soup) but service was very slow. The small place (which seats 36) was empty when we arrived Labor Day Monday at 4:30 but quickly filled up with tons of people.
author: Peijean T.

description: This place is so good and the staff is super friendly. Everything tastes authentic, way better than anything we've ever had in other cities. Highly recommend.
author: Jeannette C.

description:
Bad service，no water no checking, it requires you to ask everytime when you have needs.
It has 18% pre-tip only shown in the receipt, besides you can't see mentiomed anywhere.
Won't go anymore.
author: Alisa Z.

description: Nothing fancy but totally delicious noodles and dumplings. The beef noodle soup with tendon had spicy and savory broth with fresh homemade noodles and super soft tendon. It was delicious and easily shared between two of us. The xlb were hot and soupy with a nottoothin nottoothick shell. Good ratio of soup to dumpling. The shrimp and chive dumplings were also great. There were a lot more dumpling options on the menu so would have to come back with a big group to try more.
author: Veronica L.

description:
Soup dumplings are pretty juicy and actually have a fair amount of soup in them! The skin is a  bit thick, but that's just a minor problem--  just focus on the soup. When they came out, they were warm but not boiling hot, which was perfect because I didn't need to worry about burning my tongue.
I also really enjoyed the lamb skewers. They were extremely well seasoned and the meat is just chewy enough, but not tough. The beef noodle soup wasn't particularly impressive and the pork dumplings I ordered didn't have much flavor. Overall, portions were a bit small, but prices are very reasonable.
author: Amy C.

description: Excellent dumplings and Xian. Good service and reasonably priced. Would definitely recommend.
author: Chris C.

description:
Anytime I'm in San Francisco or any other place with a decent China town, I go searching for those darn knife cut noodles! While their noodles weren't quite what I was looking for, they were still excellent! I was there with a very large group of people and they accommodated our group size as and handled our crazy ordering beautifully. The dan dan noodles were delicious as was the lotus root salad. If you've not had lotus root, you must give it a try. Many people in my group were also happy with the soup dumplings and some of the beef dishes. I did not like the chicken dumplings. 

If you're looking for a great, almost authentic taste of China, stop in and enjoy some food at House of Xian!
author: Leanne H.

description:
Had a craving for dim sum and heard about the House of Xian Dumpling in Chinatown so had to check it out! The restaurant itself is pretty small and standard. No frills or memorable decor. The staff was very friendly and prompt which was greatly appreciated.

Their dumplings are homemade and very tasty, but the other reviews are correct in that the skin is a bit more thick than customary. However, I didn't mind the thickness at all. The soup dumplings are well crafted and have a thinner wrapping. Could go without the chive pancake, however though. That wasn't very tasty. The fried buns with a dipping sauce were unbelievably tasty! Very good and must try as a more dessert oriented dish. 

Overall, good food and quick service!
author: Kayla U.

description:
Good dumplings and pea shoots. Shanghai dumplings for days. You gotta figure out how to eat them: people either go for bite the top OR bite the edge. I'm a top-person myself but to each their own.

Anyway, solid dumplings. Recommend it.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Came in really hopeful. Dumplings were fresh and tasty. But after specifically asking the waiter if the soup dumplings were homemade or made here and being assured so, to our dismay that was not the case. 

These soup dumplings are the same exact brand that my family eats at home, only that they're being sold for twice the price as advertised as real. We didn't fly to San Fran to eat frozen soup dumplings you can get from a local h mart. 

If we were told they weren't made here, we wouldn't have ordered them in the first place. They are straight up frozen. Just disappointing
author: Tim X.

description: Noodle was awesome. Hand made and cooked very well. Beef tender noodle soup was great. Soy milk was put in with ice, which is not good - soy milk is like beer, you don't put ice inside the drink. Cucumbers was not made with Japanese Asian cucumber so is not good. Seaweed salad was lack of garlic and not cut so too long and hard to eat. Pan fried dumplings was good but not the best.
author: Anya C.

description: Came here on a Sunday night with a group of 6 because the other restaurant we wanted to go to up the street had stopped seating at 9 PM. Pleasantly surprised with the quality food, excellent flavors, and fantastic service. Noodles are hand made. We all got noodle soups and the food was excellent. Definitely recommend. Chili oil was top notch. Decor is not much but who cares when the food is this good?
author: Ed K.

description:
Our most recent find on our SF Dumpling Hunt!

Small place but got a nice seat near the window. 

Shrimp & chives dumplings were definitely homemade, with the thick skin but the filling could be more plump. Tried to pace myself but still forgot to chew because yum. 

Boyfriend enjoyed his XiaoLongBao. Nothing fancy, just delicious. 

We shared the beef noodle soup whose broth is pretty spicy than what I'd like for this entree. I love chewing on the noodles but would ask for a different broth. 

Quick, simple service. Food comes out fast but if you plan on ordering alot, get a bigger table.
author: Katy Q.

description: Was really craving XLB. Unfortunately I found the dumplings   Sad, tiny and flavorless.
author: Shanta S.

description: Delicious noodle with spicy beef! It is a very clear restaurant with good prices. The hand pulled noodles were perfection and the broth had just the right amount of spice to it. The beef was very tender and delicious.
author: Megan H.

description: I liked this place a lot. The food was fresh, piping hot, affordable, tasty. All was good other than Dan Dan noodles. I love the hot and sour soup, salt and pepper wings, Chinese broccoli, plentiful tea. All in all a hidden gem winner.
author: Andrew K.

description: This place is a little hidden gem in Chinatown. The beef noodle soup is a "must" try. We always crave for the beef noodle soup at least once a week. We love to come back every week. Not to be mention, the dumplings are so good because it's homemade.
author: Yelper G.

description:
***Bad service. 
*** Food service was slow. 
*** 18% Gratuity was automatically added. 

Seriously, I didn't think you guys deserve 18% tips on my last visit due to the service I received but I felt obligated to pay. I'll never go back again.
author: Jenny Y.

description:
The food is really good, particularly the soup dumplings.  It's also pretty cheap.

The service, however, is pretty dreadful.  We ordered two dishes and the person I was with was finished eating before my order was even brought to the table.  No apology for the excessive wait.  I'm actually not sure the waitress said anything at all to us aside from when she walked over to take our order.
author: Jason F.

description: Amazing, delicious food at a good price. Would highly recommend to anyone visiting China Town. It's proper food for the most adventurous and the least adventurous, they have a large menu.
author: Jack H.

description: Don't come here. The soup dumplings are frozen. We asked the server if they made the dumplings themselves, and she said yes prior to us ordering. We quickly discovered they were the exact same frozen dumplings we have at home. When we approached her about it after, she said they had made them, froze them, then reheated. A lie. What a waste of $.
author: Jim X.

description: I was seeking authentic Chinese food when entering this restaurant in San Francisco's Chinatown. Unfortunately I was greeted by rushed service as well as food that was not very authentic. Xian is know for spicy food and dumplings. I lived there for a while and of course I knew I wouldn't be able to get the exact same food. But what I got was not even close. Also they charged me extra for rice when ordering a dish that traditionally is eaten with rice. On top of the bad service they charged me an extra 2$ on my debit card. I'm more than unhappy and frustrated with my experience here. Definitely not a place I would come back to.
author: Kristina J.

description: I'm surprised by the low rating, maybe I just found the best things on the menu. I have never been here but I regularly order the soup dumplings and the braised beef soup for delivery through grub hub. The soup is spicy and the hand pulled noodle is so delicious.
author: Catherine G.

description:
The SO wanted some xlb aka soup dumplings and had read good reviews about this place.

Location: It's located between Chinatown and the Financial District so not as crowded on the street. Inside is a different story. Tables are small and fill up fast, no bar.

Service: Ok. Expect to hear Mandarin first, but English is also spoken. My water did not get refilled automatically though.

Food: This is my first xlb experience. It was good but I don't have much of a reference point. The SO said that good xlbs have thinner skins and more broth, but the flavor was good. We also ordered some Chinese broccoli and won tons, all decent accompaniments.

How to eat a xiao long bao (according to the SO): Place an xlb on your soup spoon. Add vinegar and/or dumpling sauce as desired. Take a pea sized bite on the side near the bottom of the dumpling. Slowly drink the soup from the dumpling, taking caution in case it's very hot. Eat the remaining dumpling by putting the soup spoon into your mouth. Use chopsticks to help hold the dumpling in place as needed during this process.
author: Sue V.

description:
Solid, consistent restaurant in Chinatown. I make a stop here the past 2 times I was in San Francisco. It's one of those places you can get in and get out fairly quickly. 

The handpulled noodles are my favorite. I love the spicy beef hand pulled noodles. They're perfectly spicy, but not the type of spicy where I'm in pain. The noodles are good. Really good. I love the texture of the hand pulled noodles, they were literally perfect. 

The dumplings are good. Not the best I ever had, but still pretty decent. The waitress forgot to put in my order for Shanghai soup dumplings, but the noodles were enough to fill me up. The service is quick. They're nicer than some Asian places. 

I don't know what it is about that spicy beef noodles, but I am seriously obsessed with them. Try it, you won't regret it. I miss it so much now that I'm not on the West Coast. I guarantee you the next time I'm in San Francisco, you'll find me here at one point.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Came on a Wednesday night and the store was pretty empty. While we were there, the resturant filled up and there were a lot of take-out pick-ups. 
We had ordered the beef noodle soup, soup dumplings, and chilli dumplings. The beef noodle soup was served with a hair on the inner side of the bowl. When it was pointed out, the waitress quickly removed it and left like nothing had happened. Not a word of apologies or anything. The soup dumplings were okay, not as soupy as some other places but the wrapper was the right thickness. The chilli dumplings were disappointing as they were not spicy. The sauce tasted more like vinegar than chilli.
Probably not coming back.
author: Anne C.

description:
I came here with my family late night for dinner since they were craving some Asian noodles, and the Chong Qing Xiao Mian was closed. My dad thought to give it a chance, since this store was located right beside it. 

Not only were the spicy noodle options not spicy, the noodle were not authentic. And the veggie portions were small (even for Canadians)! 

Lastly they charged us 18% service fees because we were seated at their "large" table (for 6 people), even though we were 5 people. Honestly I would have let this slide, but given that I was not pleased with the food, and their service was certainly not 18% worth, I disputed with the servers and finally got them to take off the fees, and instead tipped them only 10%.
author: Aj X.

description: XLB was cold. There was no soup. It tasted gross for the price. Even Trader Joe's dumplings have soup in them. Their fried rice was not good either. Their pricing is a tourist trap. You can find cheaper and better dumplings in sunset district.
author: Ann L.

description:
Yes, yes, yes, I'm going to shout out the same thing as everyone else: the  Xiao Long Bao. Soup dumplings, man. There's a reason that everyone shouts them out here and yes, yes, yes, you can order other things and I'm sure it's a wonderful and rich menu that deserves exploration.

But the reason that so many people talk about them is because they're so good. Two of us went and ordered a double serving and I could have eaten them all night. So yes, yes, yes, whatever you do be sure to add an order of them. I mean, the place has "dumpling" in the title of the restaurant, so you're pretty much morally obligated to do it.

Homemade dumplings, a nice floral salad with some kick. Yes. Yes. Yes. This is the kind of place where you duck in with a friend and have a real conversation and soak up the Chinese comfort food.
author: Jeffrey S.

description:
Large variety of dumplings including lamb dumplings which I never had before.
They accept credit card which is awesome for a restaurant in Chinatown.
Vegetarian options are also available!
author: Justin W.

description: Everything was excellent, both food-wise and service-wise. The waitress held a boiling hot bowl of soup for nearly a whole minute as she moved around the table to give it to one of our party members. We couldn't bare the heat of the bowl for more than 3 seconds!
author: Dylan C.

description: Terrible pork noodles and service, dumplings did not arrive by the time we finished eating!
author: Ekana K.

description:
What a lousy restaurant! Too much spice on everything!
The dumpling stuffing is not even fresh and the soy drink has a weird taste. 
I was starving but still couldn't eat anything. This is absolutely THE worst food I have ever had.
author: Frank W.

description:
Dooooode! I'm not sure why this place has lower stars?!?! I was seriously debating it, but I am soooo glad I came. 
Beef noodle soup- spicy, flavorful and delicious!!! Noodles were fantastic. Beef was realllly good. Sometimes I just leave it, but it was super tasty and nice texture 
Wantons in chili oil- I'm in love! These were soooooo good. The wanton is fresh and perfect. The inside is very flavorful and the chili oil just makes them perfection! They are not very spicy at all, but it doesn't even need it because it's so well balanced. 
Soup dumplings- Really impressed! I've had soup dumplings a few times before and I kind of regarded them as a novelty. The broth was super duper good! The little meat filling was a tad bland... I'd add some green onion up in there. The dumpling was a perfect texture and honestly when they got cold they were still really good! 
The tea was probably the only thing that I had that was just ok. There is a great bubble tea spot you can walk in just down the street though ;) The service was friendly and swift. The prices are excellent as well!
author: Tessa C.

description: I'm a huge fan of Xian foods and dumplings so this place definitely hit the spot! We ordered the soup dumplings, lamb skewers and the beef noodle soup to split between three people, which was the perfect amount of food for a light dinner. The prices were very reasonable as well.
author: Alice S.

description: In Chinatown, I always look for the restaurant with the least amount of tourists and white people. That's totally racist, I know. But that's how you know you're about to get the real deal. The only people in this joint, were Chinese students. Not Chinese Americans. I'm talking straight up Chinese kids. I noticed one of the reviewers complained about the Kung Pao chicken.  If you're just looking for Americanized Chinese food then you've missed the point of eating at a restaurant that specializes in regional cuisine.
author: William B.

description: Had cabbage and chicken dumpling here and thoroughly enjoyed it. Will surely come came back here just for dumplings :)
author: Puneet K.

description: The soup dumplings here are very very good. The skin is chewy and durable but not too thick and the soup and filling are super delicious and soft. The price is also very good for the amount of food you get and the service is fast! This place is relatively small so it's not great for large groups but is definitely some place good for Asian comfort food.
author: Amy W.

description:
I had some hopes on their dumpling when it called themselves House of Xian dumpling.  I was wrong!!  We ordered 2 dumplings - pork with bok Choy and shrimp/chive/pork.  I can honestly say the packaged frozen ones are a lot better especially the shrimp/chive/pork one.  It had no flavor!  We also ordered soy milk, braised beef noodle soup, dan dan noodle, spicy wonton but they gave us spicy dumpling instead.  As you can imagine how good was the spicy dumpling - another fail!  

My recommendation is skip the dumpling, ask for less sweet on the soy milk as they put 2 huge spoonful sugar in 1 cup.  The only good things are the noodles.  The braised beef noodle was good and the dan dan noodle is average.
author: C S.

description:
Finally had a chance to visit this place.

It did not disappoint!

The dumplings were REALLY, really good. Damn. I don't think they even did anything special to it other than just boil it. Tasted really good though

Get the hot soy milk. They keep it in a hot pot so it's REAL hot, so be careful. But man, does the soy milk taste awesome. I've never tasted soy milk so good

The juicy pork buns where ok. Not a lot of soup inside, but not bad either. The beef noodles were pretty good, with a good broth and soft noodles

Overall, a cool place that's worth going back again and again
author: Henry L.

description: This probably is the most disappointing place for me. Just some super market level dumplings with weird lamp skewers... Even though the spicy source is not Chinese style...
author: Zzz C.

description: Food was amazing! Service was great! In town for vacation and this place hit the spot!
author: Kenia C.

description:
Cake here for a quick early lunch with some out of town visitors. Since we couldn't get to the Sunset/Richmond district in a reasonable time, we came to this spot in Chinatown to fulfill some xiaolongbao cravings. 

What we ordered for 4 people: 

XIAOLONGBAO: pretty tasty soup dumplings with decently thin skin. The soup was plentiful and tasty.

CABBAGE & PORK DUMPLINGS: pork was tender and cabbage gave nice texture. These were light but filling.

GREEN ONION PANCAKES: the outsides were nice and crispy brown. I'm used to thinner pancakes that are more chewy, but I enjoyed the crispy exterior. I wish there were a bit more green onions though.

HOUSE SPECIAL CHOW MEIN: hand pulled noodles were fresh and had a QQ texture. Came in a big portion with lots of meat.

Service was a bit slow once the lunch rush came. I would get here by noon on a weekend otherwise there is a bit of a wait.

Overall we had a large portion of food for a great price. I'd come back for the soup and regular dumplings.
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
Amazing dumplings... shrimp and chive, excellent fried rice, delicious onion pancakes.
Definite recommendation.
author: Ross N.

description:
Dumpling restaurant next to house of nanking in fidi. Limited seating, friendly service uncharacteristic of Chinese places. 

Pan fried pork dumplings - 3/5 - Needed to be fluffier, more moist and more flavorful.
Beef pancake - 5/5 - It's actually a beef dumpling fried inside of the pancake. Both unique and delicious. 
Pork dumplings in chili oil - 2/5 - Too much cabbage, sauce not spicy enough. 
XLB - 5/5 - Best XLB I've had so far in the city. Balanced sauce, gentle flavor, decent wrapper. 

Overall, this might be my new go to xlb spot because both the beef pancake and the xlb were "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description: A friend brought me here since I'm a fan of soup noodles. We both ordered the Braised Beef Noodle Soup ($8.95). To start off, the bowl was freaking huge! It could've fed two. But at the same time, one could probably finish the entire bowl by themselves because it's so delicious! The beef was super tender and the soup was incredibly flavorful with the spices all mixed in. There's even some bok choy mixed in with all the hand-pulled noodles. I'm not as much of a fan of thick noodles, but everyone else made it quite enjoyable. We also shared the Green Onion Pancake ($5.95), which was doughy yet crispy. Overall, great comfort Chinese food!
author: Cindy Z.

description:
I love the chicken and corn dumplings here! The dumplings have thick skin so they taste very comforting and home-y.

The beef noodle soup satisfies my craving although the broth is kind of bland, but I prefer it to it's neighbor's (ChongQing) beef noodle soup. The one at ChongQing is way too oily for me, and I hate when I can't drink the soup in a noodle soup!!

All of the other small dishes are pretty tasty. All in all, a cheap and delicious place to go to when you're craving some comforting dumplings/noodles/carb dishes. :)
author: Sophia L.

description:
Small little joint on the outskirts of Chinatown near the more touristy House of Nanking.  I'm really digging the lamb options since that's kind of rare at Chinese restaurants (except Old Mandarin Islamic).  I really wanted to try the Beef Noodle Soup everyone raves about, but it was a warm day (for San Francisco) so I couldn't bring myself to it.  The dumplings and skewers were great though.

Grilled Lamb Skewed [sic]: Full of cumin-y and lamb-y tastiness.  Thin slices of lamb stretched on a skewer with nice charred bits through out.  No gristle, just goodness.

Shanghai Soup Dumpling: A decent xialongbao.  Some soup (i.e. pork fat) inside, though not overflowing.  I've had better, but have also had worse.

Beef Pancake: A little light on the beef and heavy on the dough, but still tasty.  Kinda dry, so bring on the soy sauce and/or chili sauce.

Boiled West Lake Lamb Dumpling: I love lamb and I love dumplings, so this is a perfect pairing for me.  A lot more personality than beef or pork.  Generous portion.
author: Adam B.

description: Very nice variety of dumplings with above average Shanghai dumplings and the pan fried kind. Great for a group of 8-10 friends because of its great location near Chinatown and for it being like $9 per dumpling order. I think this place is very under-rated. The beef noodle soup is great, especially the beef cubes which were surprisingly tender.
author: Young Y.

description:
I've been here three times now and wanted to give them another try after the first time. This is a decent spot for XLB if you work in Fidi area. However, it's totally not worth traveling afar. 

We got the XLB and the dough was very thick. There is some juice in it but it's not the greatest. We also got shrimp fried rice and it was your standard Chinatown fried rice. The shrimp tasted frozen (def need some shaoxing wine to balance out the taste !) 

We also tried the beef noodle soup and the porkchop noodle soup. The beef noodle soup was VERY bland. I expected a robust deep strong flavor like other Taiwanese noodle soup. This almost tasted like they used can beef broth. The third time we came I decided to try the porkchop noodles. Most places fried their porkchop to perfection and serve on the side with a generous portion of noodle soup with a good broth. However, they dumped the whole porkchop in the soup and the fried dough was mushy. Also the soup wasn't any different and was your standard wonton soup broth...

I also got green onion pancake once. Though it's a big portion it was all dough, barely any green onions in it. Green onion pancake supposed to be thin, pan fried to perfection, and filled with green onions! This was not the case. 

I'm so disappointed and really wanted some good Taiwanese food in the area for my lunch spots! I will come back for their XLB if I want to splurge.
author: Sarah I.

description: Now my go to place when I crave dumplings.  I also tend to recommend this place when I meet up with friends.  My favorites are Shanghai soup dumplings, chili oil wonton, enoki mushroom salad, Dan Dan noodles, wide bean noodle salad, and bean curd stick with cilantro.
author: Hosick F.

description:
I was completely underwhelmed. I was looking for dim sum and ended up here. The dumplings had no flavor and the dough was slimy. The garlic bok choy was very good. I sat squeezed in between people at one long table which was fine but if you are someone who doesn't like to share a table with strangers this is something to consider. 
The iced tea was well past its expiration date. With all of the other options in this neighborhood I will not be coming back.
author: Lindsay B.

description: Stopped  by for Sunday lunch. Had salt and pepper pork chop, house special chow mein, combo BBQ meatball, shrimp, beef and vegetable noodle soup. Everything was delicious but the salt and pepper pork chop was the star.
author: David F.

description:
Went to try this place out as a co worker traveled to Xainyang china and kept going on about the superiority of Xi'An noodle and dumpling dishes.
He was not wrong. 
The three of us shared pork dumplings in chili oil, house special chow mein, and the vegetable dumplings. The chili oil was both tangy and spicy, the dumplings were perfect. That was so far my best meal in Chinatown. 
Service was decent, waitress made a small mistake on the chow mein, but the manager corrected it immediately. Place was about half full on a thursday night so I suspect it might get super busy at times.
The food is totally worth a small wait however.
author: Steven W.

description: Very good traditional style Chinese food. Flavors are very clean and simple. The bok choy in garlic sauce was delicious, and you can't go wrong with the soup dumplings! Being that my wife is vegetarian and I'm not, this place was perfect with plenty of options for both of us.
author: Arun B.

description: A small, no-frills spot on the edge of Chinatown serving fresh and affordable dumplings and hand-pulled noodles, among other standard Chinese fare.  I've been here twice now, and plan to return for the fresh noodles, the boiled vegetarian dumplings (which are some of the best in SF, if you ask me) and the honey chili tofu (deep-fried chunks of tofu drizzled in sticky spicy-sweet sauce). They have several choices of noodles (flat/regular hand-pulled, egg noodle, rice noodle) that you can pair with a fairly extensive list of soup/meat/veg broths & sauce bases. We had the flat hand-pulled noodles with garlic shrimp and were impressed with how fresh and light it tasted, not to mention how generous the serving was. The shrimp were delicately seasoned and perfectly cooked, and the broth was light but flavorful. The additions of thinly sliced celery and garnish of cilantro made this a really nicely composed dish. I think this place is going to be my standard when I have a dumpling craving (which is not rare!)
author: Hillary D.

description: Homemade noodles and hot soy milk is amazing. They only have a few items which means each dish get a lot of attention. I like the quiet foggy nights here.
author: Stacey T.

description:
Maybe I shouldn't be allowed to write this review, as I have a grandpa who is basically a certified dumpling whisperer and will dish up the best you ever had. 

But nonetheless, I thought the food was very very mediocre. Couldn't really decide whether or not the dumplings were prepackaged frozen ones or homemade. Honestly, save your money and just buy frozen ones from the grocery store if you're planning on coming here. One of the biggest factors for me is the skin- it was just too thick. I prefer for the wrapper to be rolled thin enough so that you can see the filling inside easily, and I think this is how it's done most traditionally. The filling was kinda chewy and not juicy whatsoever. 

I only got dumplings so I can't speak for the other food. They do look good though, kinda wish I tried something else. 

Also the service was kinda shoddy and I waited forever to get my bill, even though they made eye contact with me and saw that I was done several times. But that's not really the reason for the stars, as this kind of "whatever" attitude is very typical with Chinese restaurants. 

Wouldn't come here again (also a little pricy for Chinatown imo).
author: Jenny Z.

description:
I ordered Shanghai Soup dumpling($8.98) and boiled cabbage &pork dumpling ($8.95)and one Tsingtao beer. No price for the beer on the menu. Guess how much total cost for these three orders? 
The waitress showed me the bill, it's $30.50  , she told me no tip included. 
When I questioned about the bill, she corrected the price twice. Finally she charged me $25.44( the beer $5.50).
So soso terrible!!!
There is no half star rating, I have to choose one.
author: Yanjun J.

description:
Simple restaurant. I was looking for xiao long bao. It was all I want flying to San Francisco only because I would think that it's better there than it is in Chicago. 

The service was ok, but I had to leave a review only because I had to HUNT for xiao long baos... And it was a good fix!
author: Linh L.

description:
I have never been treated so poorly i my life here!
I went in to get a table ok, once she found out it was just for me, one, everything changed.
She said lets make it to go which i did not want, i should have walked, but said fine.
Never been there so had no idea what I wanted but she kept rushing me to order and pay asap!
She wanted the table i was at so asked me to wait outside!!
I was dressed very nicce, a caucasian female and highly insulted!
Do not go here, they treat locals like dirt
author: Sue P.

description:
Great soup dumplings. The skin is not too thick and there are plenty of juice in the dumplings. Side dishes are delicious; lamb skewers, pig ears, spicy wanton. 

Service is quick and friendly. I will definitely come here again whenever I'm in Chinatown. 

Suggestion: Maybe a little bit more shredded ginger to go with the soup dumplings.
author: Tina R.

description:
-BEWARE OF ADDED GRATUITY.-

After receiving terrible service, the waitresses busy texting on their phone... they dare add 18% SERVICE CHARGE for doing the bare minimum. After asking the waitress about it, she looked at the bill and came back with a new on WITHOUT the added 18%. Never again will I return to this establishment!!
author: Kevin L.

description: I had delicious beef noodle soup here and pretty good soup dumplings. It is a small place but I highly recommend it for lunch, which is what I went for. The broth of the beef noodle soup was so flavorful and satisfying and the beef was just melt-in-your-mouth tender. They really know how to make it. After traveling to Taiwan earlier this year and having the famous beef noodle soup several times there, I was very pleasantly surprised to find soup just as delicious at this restaurant. The decor in this place is very nice, but the food is absolutely the best feature and this restaurant is well worth the effort to find. 5 stars, very authentic and super yummy! I will definitely eat here again!
author: K L.

description:
Saw House of Xian Dumpling across the street as I was walking up Columbus and decided to stop in for some Saturday afternoon dumplings. Now this place does not specialize in dumplings, they have lots of other options as well - beef noodle soup, chicken fried rice, etc. 

I am not personally a huge fan of Chinese food, so I decided to stick with soup. Ordered the Beef Noodle soup, which is slightly spicy. Along with that, I had the pork dumplings with spicy oil. Didn't really love the dumplings but I think that is just because I am not a fan of the cuisine to begin with. I did like the soup though, nice flavor, not too spicy, and delicious beef. I do wish there was more beef in the soup though, only had about 3 pieces in a giant bowl. 

As well, the staff were very friendly and the service was quick.
author: Aletta B.

description:
This little restaurant makes me feel warm and fuzzy inside. I would consider all their food as comfort food. 

Their menu consists mostly of boiled dumplings and hand pulled noodles. I ordered the green onion pancake, shanghai pork buns, and the xiao long bao. I came because I wanted some late night xiao long bao, They open till pretty late so that was the main reason why I came. I was not disappointed! Their XLB is on the sweeter side. I wished it were more soupy but I'll live. I absolutely hate when I order XLB and they're deflated with no soup. The dumplings came out fresh and plump. No complaints here! The shanghai pork buns were something that I've never tried before. They're a pan fried bao stuffed with a soft meatball. They were very good! The pork inside was marinated well and was really really moist and tender inside the bao. Their green onion pancake was underwhelming. I'm used to chewy green onion pancakes but these were dry for my liking. 

The service was fine. It was really busy as the Chinese New Year Parade has just ended but the waitresses were still attentive. 

Overall, I liked the dumplings and their bao. They really do it well. My bill was really expensive for three items, it came out to $40 in the end. This place is great to come for some late night comfort food.
author: Sharon D.

description:
Decent noodles, good service! I Asked them for extra Chive for my Tomato egg noodles, and the server gave me a lot!
pretty good Chinese food, reminds me of the Noodles place I used to go in China....
author: Emily H.

description:
My nostalgia for Beijing led me here. This place was empty at 6pm on a Friday night. 

Beef Pancake - paled in comparison to the ones I had back in the motherland, but it satisfied my craving. They skimp on the meat filling and the skin was too doughy. Slim pickings in SF though so beggars can't be choosers.

Chinese Broccoli w/ Oyster Sauce - Pretty standard.
