This place is cheap, but cash only. Will be back to try the dumplings!
author: Lucy N.

description: Worst potstickers I've ever had. Pork was undercooked and extremely bland, the rest was super doughy and dry. Pork buns were slightly better, but still very bland and everything was super overpriced and tiny. Wish I could get my money back lol.
author: Tabitha L.

description:
Let's keep it real. This is not a luxury diner - right... So now that this is established, let me explain that I am rating this 5 stars based on a relatively no frills dining experience. That said, I will have you know that the food is better than several luxury dinning experiences I have enjoyed in the past with regard to Chinese cuisine.

At House of Xian, I had the Beef Noodle Soup with the complimentary green tea:)
.... and the delicious soup dumplings. 

The Beef Noodle soup is one of the best noodle soups I have had in SF. Now, needless to say I am a repeat offender when it comes down to the Chinese cuisine and I have had many noodle soups. From the picture you can see the vibrant colors and hopefully from this review you can take me seriously when I say the noodles are fresh and delicious. The dumplings are also equally equip with freshness which I am always pleased by as I operate on a strict NO STALE DUMPLING POLICY...

After reading some of the reviews, I have to say I am flabbergasted how anyone could argue with the prices at this place. But this is just my humble opinion. I encourage you to try it for yourself.

Nom Nom Nom.
author: Kimberly N.

description: This place is solid for dumplings. I would recommend going here if you are looking for dumplings or noodles.  Smaller menu but the preparations are good.
author: Anna S.

description: Dumpling is okay but super tiny. The potstickers and shanghai pan fried meat bun are not good - crust is way too thick and hard. They are fully fried instead of pan fried. Beef noodle soup doesn't taste good. Maybe I'm used to authentic Chinese dumpling places in  LA. The dumplings and pot stickers taste worst than frozen dumplings from 99 Ranch Market.
author: Kittyanne h.

description: I was very disappointed with both the beef noodle soup and the dumplings we ordered. The quality of the ingredients used were terrible and the dumplings tasted like they had been frozen for a long time before serving.
author: Lucy L.

description: After a night out we decided to walk our way to this place, we were the last costumers that night before they closed, after we order in less than 5min we got our food. And everything was sooooo delicious.
author: Tvo M.

description: By fluke we ate here since House of Nanking was a disappointment for our family.  What I loved here were the good broth that accompanied the handmade pulled noodles.  The Dan Dan noodles were delicious.  My daughter ate the braised beef broth with wide noodles, I ate the same thing but with tendons.  We were so satisfied that we came back the next day. I also love that it seems CLEAN!!  I will not eat in dingy, dirty, places no matter how good they say they are.
author: Paul L.

description:
Food: 3.0/5.0
Service: 2.0/5.0
Value: 3.5/5.0
Decor: 2.5/5.0
Overall: 3.0/5.0

Okay food with subpar service.  The noodles are pretty decent across the board but most of the other items aren't that great, dumplings included.  Unfortunately, the quality has gone down over the past couple of years.
author: Damian W.

description: The XLB was so so, soup yes, but the skin was a bit thick.  The dumplings were pretty good, but not as good as Dumpling Empire.  The rest of the fare was standard, service was good.  We walked there, just remember parking in Chinatown sucks
author: Min C.

description:
2nd time to House of Xian Dumpling think I ordered pretty bad this time.

I got:

Chive & fish dumplings $7.95 - very salty dumplings!  skip it.

boy (sic) choy oyster sauce $5.25 - just boiled bok choy w/ some oyster sauce, not very tasty, skip it.

boiled black sesame mochi $4.25 - 6 small mochi dumplings w/ the black sesame lava - I thought it was just ok, nothing special.

Wanted take-out box, lady took my bok choy in the back to box up and put in a plastic bag, then she charged me 10c for the bag, I said No to the bag and had it taken off my bill!  Evil!  Bring your own bag here!!

Charged it, their minimum is $15, made it.
author: Ann L.

description:
Very unfriendly even by Chinese restaurant standards, I thought it was an exaggeration when people were saying how rude they were but it's not- no greeting, no thanks, acknowledgment, etc etc.

Overpriced and total rip-off, check my uploaded picture to see how small the xiaolongbao (steamed dumplings) are. Literally the size of the quarter and it costs like 8-9 bucks for an order of 8. I finished eating my 'meal' in literally 5 minutes before leaving to get some real food.

Finally, not authentic- at all! I've had better dumplings prepared from a bag of frozen ones from a Chinese supermarket. Not at all close to the great dumplings we used to have at a fraction of the price in my hometown of Shanghai. Don't listen to the people who've never had better and can't tell...
author: Tim L.

description:
Service: Horrible. The waitress literally threw the food on the table. She was probably imagining herself throwing the food on the floor so I'll eat it like a dog. It wasn't even that busy (restaurant was probably 20% full at most). Also, when I asked her I wanted to change something in my order literally 3 minutes after I made the order, she snapped at me and said "TOO LATE, FOOD ALREADY FINISHED COOKING!" ....3 minutes?! Whatever...

Food: Beef noodle soup tasted like those safeway canned beef broth + soy sauce... What is everyone talking about? It was horrible! The random meat chunks in there also tasted like expired meat... The dumpling skin was nice and chewy, BUT the meat inside was UNDERCOOKED. I didn't want to deal with the waitress (she would probably snap at me again and spit in my food) so I took the dumplings to-go and microwaved it at home to cook it through...
author: Betty T.

description:
It's a chill and low key mama papa kind of spot for steamed dumplings, steamed pork buns (xiao long baos) and hand pulled fresh noodle soup! 

I like their hand pulled flat noodles with beef soup becuase it was so homely, the beef was tender and well flavored!  Yum!  They do have lamb skewers, Xian (province part of China) style.  It was tasty as well!  I love their black vinegar on the side!  It's great for the steamed entrees, flaky grilled pancakes and generally with everything!

It's fairly priced for the items that they have and service is on point!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Dumplings 5/5
Potatoes (cold dish) 5/5
Soup dumplings 4/5- meat/soup flavor was not as good as other place
author: Ingrid C.

description: This satisfied everyone's Chinese food craving! The staff was super helpful and everyone loved their meal! We ordered a variety of their dumplings, egg flower soup, don don noodles, pork fried rice, and pea shoots!
author: Walkyria W.

description:
We were in town for the holiday weekend - and heat wave.  It was close to 100f as we walked in Chinatown, and as we walked by this place we saw a meal served near the window.  It looked so good we decided to try the place - even with no A/C.

Glad we did.  The food was fresh, and carefully prepared.  Even though the kitchen had to be sweltering, the chef took the time to make some very nice dumplings.  

The Cucumber with peanuts salad was fresh and crisp

The Mongolia Beef was as good as any I have had - it was more beef than anything else on the plate

The Cabbage & Pork dumplings were fresh & carefully prepared.  Very tasty

It was just too hot to try the noodle soup - it looked good though.

We will go back next time we are in SF.  There was plenty of meat in the meat dishes, the waitresses were friendly and quick.  The place was clean.  Serving sizes were on par with any other Chinese restaurant
author: Brad H.

description: Great dumplings , sweet waitress but the manager or owner is very rude I'd still come back based on the tastiness of their dumpling but it probably be to go from now on
author: Anjelica H.

description: We ran into the resturant without doing any research. the food is ok. but I was forced to pay 18% 'service charge' Check your bill before u pay.
author: Weiyi W.

description: Decent dumpling dough and filing flavor but not enough fillings. XLB skins are too thick and the beef noodle soup too sweet and not enough depth and complexity in flavor. Doable in a pinch on a cold summer evening.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Absolutely delicious! Brought baby cousins who never eat anything that isn't bread and they were super happy with green onion pancakes, chicken skewers and fried rice. Adults enjoyed many dumplings and dim sum, all perfect. Would come back.
author: Miranda H.

description:
I really like this place. It's a really small place, and if you come here at peak times, you probably have to wait. That being said, my office is only a couple blocks over, so take-out is a great option for us. 

I hate that people say this is where you go when the House of Nanking is too full. Screw that, as a native San Franciscan, AND a Chinese person, I'll tell you that we do NOT go to House of Nanking. Tourists, fine. But us? No. XiAn is right next door, and has really great quality, and HOUSE MADE foods. You know why those dumplings and noodles aren't uniform? Its homemade. 

I've had a lot of their foods, but things that stood out:

Lamb dumplings - very lamby. Like gamey. So if you want that great lamb taste, do it. If you're not a fan of it, don't get it. Its pure lamb.

Pork dumplings - light, and very delicious.

Noodle Soups (with dumplings) - also light and delicious. Great on a cold SF day. 

Potato appetizer - Surprisingly delicious. It comes out cold, so don't freak out. Its good though

Green Onion Pancake - I've had better...but this one wasn't bad at all. It gets you your fix. 

Xiao Long Bao - First of all, never call it XLB's. No Chinese person would know wtf you're talking about. Call it soup dumplings if you can't say Xiao Long Bao. Theirs are pretty good. Though not as soupy as I'd like.

The service is pretty on point. For two people running the entire outside floor, it's not bad.
author: Lily W.

description:
I discovered this little hole in the wall during my internship this past summer and I can say its become one of my favorite Chinese food places in San Francisco. As I was working long hours, this place was one of the few dinner restaurants open late and had great to-go options. Location wise, it is super close to Fidi and is also very affordable and fast. I would highly recommend stopping by here and ordering a large bowl of beef noodle soup or xiao long bao (soup dumplings). 

[Food]
For the price and the quantity, the food here is amazing. They have a great selection of homemade dumplings. Two of my favorite things to eat in this world is beef noodle soup and xiao long baos, two items that are all-stars here. The beef noodle soup is a large portion and made with handmade thick noodles. The beef is also very fresh and the soup is very tasty. The xiao long baos have a great amount of soup in them and is very fresh as well. I've also tried the green onion pancakes and pan-fried buns, and both have been great as well. I definitely need to expand my options when I eat here again, but I have an undying love for beef noodle soup.

[Decor]
It's a little hole in the wall Chinese restaurant. For its price point and convenience, there's nothing super special here. 

[Service]
It seems to be a family run restaurant and I've personally become friends with the lady that runs the store. She's very friendly and I speak Chinese to her. While sometimes you need to flag down the servers to ask for anything, it is your usual Chinese restaurant. The service is very fast and the food comes out very quickly.

I highly recommend giving this place a try. It's a standout little Chinese restaurant that's convenient, fast, and tasty.
author: Alice Z.

description:
The service here was SO frustrating. Maybe all the white people got better service since we're in FiDi? Either way, I tried to get the waitress's attention every time she walked by me and she never looked my way. I had to EHHH HEMMM very loudly in order for her to finally notice me. Same with at the end of my meal. It took me FOREVER to pay, and get a box. I had to just walk up to the cash register with my money.

The food was alright. I had pork dumplings in soup with the flat noodles. $9 after tax and tip. Next time I want to try dumplings not in soup.
author: Angela L.

description:
Cut the crap. This place is awesome! The only reason anyone would write a negative review about this place would be because they don't want to share it. These guys deserve success.

Yeah, I was worried when I saw it was right next to House of Nanking. And there is a better-decorated restaurant with a picture menu nearby with a lot of Sichuan items on it which almost threw me off my mission. But that place was packed and the menu looked kind of small.

We got there about 2pm on a Saturday and there was plenty of room. We were astonished by the menu, which had all kinds of interesting stuff on it as well as a lot of the traditional favorites. It was hard to decide

Here's the rundown (for three very hungry people):

Spicy Beef Tendon appetizer: my compatriot noted that this was superior to where we used to go. I'd have to agree and admit that I'm a sucker for the heavier, saltier sauce.

Cucumber Salad with Peanuts: I nearly fell over when my compatriot ordered this. I mean, there was Tofu Sticks Salad With Cilantro and all kinds of fried stuff there. I was expecting sliced cucumbers, Thai-style, perhaps even accompanied with peanut sauce. Instead there was a lovely stack of cucumber toothpicks dressed in a delicate invisible sauce, and a piles naked peanuts. Fresh and delicious. Heaven, honestly.

House Braised Pork Knuckle: It took me a while to figure out this was pig foot. Once that was established I was perfectly comfortable with the way it giggled. Deeply seasoned with star anise, this is the best pig food dish you'll ever have for less than ten bucks.

Shanghai Soup Dumplings: served thoughtfully with three porcelain soup spoons, a no-nonsense version of the classic. Of all the dumplings we had, these had the thinnest skins.

Boiled Radish Beef Dumplings: This was by far the most unique thing we ordered and the standout. I'm not sure what the colored radish they're using is, but it's delicious and completely accessible. Stop whining about the thickness of the skins. They're not going to slow you down.

Chives Fish Dumpling: I love chive dumplings but they always have shrimp in them, so I was thrilled to see this. I was not disappointed. Fresh and light!

Red Bean Paste Pancake: a delicate pop-tart cut in 6 pieces, served perfectly hot, crispy, and not at all oily.

Boiled Black Sesame Mochi: six little white mochi eggs filled with sweetened black sesame, served in a glass bowl with little metal spoons. A mind-blowing finish to the meal.
author: Seth G.

description: Very average... got the XLB and was pretty disapppinted.  Dumpling skin was too thick and dumplings were not very juicy. Was about $1 per dumpling. Service was friendly tho. Perhaps the other dumplings are better.
author: Kristen L.

description: The noodles were so-so, but the lamb dumplings were very tasty.  The restaurant was nearly empty at 8 pm on a Friday night which is kind of surprising.
author: Greta G.

description:
The beef noodle soup is good but I can notice that even the noodle is house made it is not hand pulled. 

The lamp dumplings is okay, just the dough is a little thick so you need some soy sauce for it.

The food overall is okay but I don't understand why they need to put 18% service charge on our bill when we only have a party of 2 (my husband and I). I thought you would only add the mandatory service charge when you have a party of 6 or more. Is it a new trend in restaurants in Chinatown? maybe a lot of tourists do not tip??? but do they deserve 18% tips??? We are two adults and no kids and not messing up their place... I hope they put a sign somewhere in the restaurant or have the server kindly tell us. 18% for a homemade feel dumplings place... I think it is too much.
author: Emily C.

description: Was okay. Open when I walked in before 10 pm. Ordered a shrimp and chive dumpling. Tasted like an only chive dumpling. Meh.
author: Zehra A.

description: The food is not authentic at all. Noodles are not hand made. Also the shop is not clean. Chef is not professional. I can cook better.
author: Fridge M.

description: Terrible food. $10 noodle with only paper, and dear to claim Xinan traditional taste. Ask for change but still charged my card. Worst experience ever! Won't come again!
author: Xincheng M.

description: What a great and accidental fine. We intended to eat at House of Nanking but the line was too long. So my wife and I looked at the menu of House of Xian Dumpling and decided to try this place -- which is next door -- instead. The food was delicious. Soups were excellent and the dumplings were even better. The noodles in the soups are are hand pulled and fresh. We ate at House of Nanking a few days later and the food was fine. But frankly, if we next time we come back to SF we will head to House of Xian Dumpling and nowhere else!
author: Gary D.

description:
Well, this is absolutely below my Asian standard, maybe way too Americanized. Northern Chinese food should not be sweet like this, also lack of transitional species. I can not believe I am in Chinatown of San Francisco, it is more like a Chinese restaurant in a small town where not many asians around.
To be fair, if you come from China or like real Chinese food, this is not the best place to try. But I think some people might like the flavor here as well.
author: W Z.

description: I got the soup dumplings and pea sprouts. Not anything to write home about, but edible. I wouldn't seek this place out but it works for later dinner when other places are closed. Food takes a bit to come out but staff are very nice
author: Kevin D.

description: Love this restaurant.  Always eat here when I am in San Francisco.Delicious soup dumplings at very affordable prices with friendly service. There isn't much of an atmosphere so the experience is pretty utilitarian but if you're after dumplings you can't really go wrong here.Great authentic Chinese food and pleasant staff.Dan dan noodles (left) was super delicious and Dumplings in Chili Oil (right) definitely complimented the overall meal! Would definitely come here again
author: Christy M.

description:
Decent cheap spot for authentic Chinese food. The hand made noodles are good and the bok choy w/ oyster sauce is great.

The dumplings are only okay though they didn't have the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) that day. They just opened so a lot of stuff wasn't available. Would come back and check it out again.
author: Victor W.

description: XLB was a 3. Service gets a 1. Top that off with an 18 percent mandatory gratuity invariant of party size. So House of Xian Privilege gets a 2.
author: Uday B.

description:
Ugh I love this place so much! The main reason is because their shanghai dumplings are on point. But also because one day, when I have the appetite for more than shanghai dumplings, I'll try one of their noodle dishes because those look bomb too. I don't think this place can disappoint me. 

Never had an issue with seating. In fact, this restaurant always seems a bit empty. The restaurant next door is always bustling so it might be a competitor thing. But I'm staying loyal. If you're ordering the dumplings, be prepared for a little wait. But they are well worth it! The chive pancake is a nice filler in the meantime.
author: Junel S.

description:
This is a small restaurant that looks clean and well run.

The staff are friendly and they understand dinner theater. They have this cool hand pulled noodle pulling station in the middle of the small dining space. I did not appreciate how big this is in the tiny dining room, till I saw it myself.

Most of the items I tried were quite good.

Black fungus with garlic - Looks like the lungs from an alien species, but they are delicious and apparently good for your heart.

Cold beef tendon. Once you get over the plasticized meat texture, it is quite good but still prefer Z and Y's version. The Z and Y version is sliced thinner and has a has a particularly addictive numbing peppercorn chili oil sauce.

Pea Sprouts in House Broth - Very good

Curried Fish Balls - Texture is a cross between a marshmallow and a scallop. Loved these. Very good.

Pork and Vegetable Wonton Soup - Unusual tasting wontons, not as good as Hons Wun Ton House, but interesting.

Shanghai Soup Dumplings - Xiao Long Bao's - Not the best I've had but not bad either.

Pork Dumplings in Chili Oil - This one was disappointing. The dumplings were heavy and the sauce more vinegar than spice. Skip this one.

Boiled Shrimp, Pork and Chive dumpling. Quite good. I liked this one.

Overall I was very pleased with my dinner here and wish I'd tried this place sooner.
author: David T.

description: It was alright, the skin of the dumplings were a bit rough and there wasn't much of a soup inside the soup dumplings. However, for the price, it was actually pretty decent for the amount of food you got. But then again, you can just hop yourself over to Trader Joe's for some dumplings at 3.99$ and they'll prob taste better than the ones here & you'll prob get to eat them pant-less in the comfort of your own home.
author: Jessica J.

description: This place is legendary! We always get the prod dumplings, lamb skewer and sweet and sour chicken. It is all amazing! The prices are super cheap as well relative to a lot of other Chinese restaurants in the Bay Area. Definitely come here!
author: Adam M.

description: Divey china town/north beach Chinese restaurant. The mostly specialize in noodle soups and dumplings and they are all fantastic. I've had the beef and tendon noodle soup, the spicy dumplings, and the wonton soup and all are great. They are very consistent here and I've ordered from them many times. It's a great place to stop for takeout bc eating there isn't as pleasant. They are also open late.
author: Mai C.

description: Get their lamb skewers and beef noodle soup. Their dumplings and other soups are just okay. The skewers have a generous portion and the beef soup is one of the most flavorful things on the menu.
author: Kelly T.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city. The beef noodle soup with hand made noodles is absolutely delicious and some of the best that I've had. My coworkers and I crave this place pretty much every week. The appetizers are also absolutely delicious and authentic, and it all combines for a great economical and no frills meal. Good portions and well. 

The food is absolutely authentically northern Chinese, which is something that is generally harder to find in the US as most Chinese people here are from southern China. This is one of the few places that I've eaten at where it gave me nostalgia about being in China (I'm a northerner).

I see something about a health score? No way, I've probably eaten here at least once a month, if not once every one or two weeks, for the last couple years and have never had a problem.
author: Jake Z.

description: My go-to for beef noodle soup, often amazing but not always consistent. Also has great xiaolongbao and unique scallion pancakes.
author: Kimberly Y.

description: Soup dumpling had barely any soup and I waited 30 minutes in an empty restaurant. Disappointing.
author: Npauj T.

description:
Sorry if I'm not an expert on Xian food but this place occupies the same space as my previous favorite restaurant in San Francisco so I decided to stop in and have a try.
After a long day's work, I was finally able to get out late on a Saturday night and was promptly seated by the friendly staff.
I ordered Kung Pao chicken and shrimp fried rice. Much to my belly's delight, the food was served rather quickly. Just so you know, I've been to Beijing and have had this dish while there. So as a novice foodie, I like to have a benchmark on which to base my opinions. 
I thought the food was really, really good. The chicken had the right amount of heat, it wasn't greasy or overcooked.  The rice looked much different than we're accustomed to back East but it too was very good and not overdone. It  was very light tasting and, in my opinion,  the perfect companion to the chicken.
This place is just one more reason for me to pack up and move West.
author: michael c.

description:
I really enjoyed this place. We ordered the beef tendon soup, onion pancake, cucumber and peanut appetizer and lastly, Szechuan soup dumplings. The beef tendon soup was by far the stand out dish. The soup along with the noodles were delicious. The cucumber peanut starter was fresh, crunchy and a perfect light start to meal. The onion pancake was perfectly crispy. The soup dumplings were just ok. I've had juicier and better dumplings elsewhere. They weren't bad not great, just mediocre. When we got our bill,everything only cost $31.50. We were pleasantly surprised. 

Overall, I'd recommend this place if you're looking for something casual and yummy to eat while in Chinatown.
author: Lucia L.

description:
Owners, if you are out there, please, please, shake up your management team and find a way to speed up your service and turn your tables!

The food here is...shockingly amazing. I haven't made it through the menu yet because everything I've ordered has been so good I've had to order again. And after I introduced it to my co-worker from Beijing, she's insisted on returning here every time we eat lunch together. The noodle soups, the fish and shrimp dumplings, and all of the vegetables are better than I could have imagined.

It is also a great value, incredible for FiDi, and their price point is a perfect match for their presentation.

But the complaints about the slowness of the service are all on point. On my last trip in, the power was out, and the server seating us told us that service was slow because the power outage had slowed down the kitchen and made them cash only. It turned out that it was the fastest service we had received to date, but then after the power came back on, we had to wait 20 minutes after they had brought the check for them to take our payment. We waved arms and made eye contact with multiple servers, but they kept finding things to do other than take our money, set us free, and free up a table.

If not for this one nagging problem, I would give them five stars. I'll let them have four in tribute to the other aspects, and because I think this is a problem they can fix. Owners, I implore you, fix it.
author: James D.

description: We were looking for soup dumplings and found this little spot.  The dumplings were good - thinner wrappers then some I've had - so not too doughy.  Soup was flavourful - altho didn't burst out like some I've had.  This made them a bit easier to eat though.  Would definitely go again.
author: Tammy B.

description:
Cheap. Delicious, Fast. 

You can get a solid meal and have leftovers here for $7. Portions are large, as are many other Chinese restaurants portions. I came here with 3 friends we ordered way. too. much.

Here's what we ordered:

The beef in the noodle soup was good, but had very few pieces. Mostly all noodles which were supposed to be hand pulled but weren't chewy enough for my taste.

Xiao long bao, pork and chive dumplings, potstickers - all pretty good, though these things are hard to mess up imo. 

Chicken fried rice - more fragrant than expected and chicken was delicious! 

Bok choy with oyster sauce - average. What you'd expect. 

Would come back again if I'm looking for a quick affordable meal.
author: Amanda C.

description: Super easy, fast and tasty dumplings. Not the best, but for what it's worth it's pretty good. Hits the craving spot after work when I'm in the mood for xiao long bao. Noodles are pretty good too.
author: Angela N.

description:
I checked in here and the first thing I saw was a health alert pop-up. Then I got queasy. But my husband said he was here the last time he was in SF and it was tasty.

Let me tell you, the owners/staff don't give a fuuuuk because she was in happy spirits when we walked in. For a tiny quite literal hole-in-the-wall, I had pretty awesome service! The food came out in proper formation with little delay; waters are refilled promptly; and the most important note, I did not get sick from eating there.

The beef noodle soup is outta this world. I see some reviews are like "nbd" - but y'all, I'm an Asian stuck in the 'great' state of Texas and this is like heaven in the mouth. Another favorite were the soup dumplings. I couldn't stop eating; I got so bloated and ruined my own afternoon lying in the hotel bed. 

WORTH IT.
author: Tania P.

description:
I've been on the search for a decent soup dumpling aka xiaolongbao place in SF. Despite the name including "dumpling", this place was not the one.

First, the good. Even though it was still crowded when we strolled in at 1:45 pm on a Saturday afternoon, service was excellent and very prompt. Yay!

The food though, was just lowkey disappointing. We ordered the soup dumplings, chives and pork dumplings, and mustard greens. Nothing was particularly bad, but it's not really anything to write home about either. The dumpling skin was not "Q" as my mom's Asian dumpling making group calls it (more on the sticky side) and there was hardly any soup in the soup dumplings, but you can try it for yourself if you're already in the area. If you do end up coming, I would recommend getting a plate of just dumplings instead of the soup dumplings.
author: Deanna C.

description:
This is one of the best dumpling and xiao long bao place you'll find in the city, for a rather low price compared to it's competitors. 

1. Service:

The service at the restaurant was quick, polite, and efficient. When you ask for something, they do not forget, and get you that something right away. They always have someone looking out, in case a customer needs service. The food comes out quick, and there's not awkward wait between ordering and eating.

2. Food

The Xiao Long Bao here are one of my favourite dishes the the restaurant. For about $8.95, you get about 8 of them, which isn't a bad price. Have them with the red vinegar, and it'll be so bless. 

The also have a beef noodle soup with hot chilli peppers. It's really good too, especially if you like a little kick in your food. The size of the bowl is pretty decent with the thick type of noodle. Personally, I would say it is as filling as a big mac with a side of small fries at McDonald's, just for perspective. 

Finally, if you're looking for the drink, the soy milk is good at this place. I personally like it cold but you can also get it hot. They have the sweet version (which is what most people are familiar with) but they also have the savoury version of the drink. It's quite unique and really a hit or miss with a lot of people. However, if you have not tried it before, you should try it here! They do it quite well!! 

3. Wait for seats

This place isn't as packed as their neighbours but I find that this place is a bit better for the quality to price ratio. It's a small shack but rarely has a wait, so if you're looking for something quick. this is your place.

Overall Comments:

All in all, great place with friendly servers. I highly recommend this place if you are in town.

Notes: 
They only accept VISA if the bill is over $15. Else, you'll need to pay with cash.
author: Kenny C.

description:
We came here around 9pm in search of an authentic Chinese meal. Unfortunately when we arrived, there was a gas problem so the owners emphasized there would be delays. We were so tired that we didn't want to go search for another place that was open and stayed, opting for the longer wait. The waitresses were very apologetic and polite, so there's a star for that. 

The food, however, was very lacking. Because it's known as a dumpling house, I got veggie dumpling noodle soup, hoping I could get a good combo of both dishes. However, both noodle soup and dumplings were extraordinarily plain and bland. I'm not sure whether the food quality would have improved if their stoves were fully functional, but from my experience with the soup noodle dumplings, I definitely do not recommend that. It's something I could have made myself at home in 10 minutes. I suggest saving your money and go elsewhere instead of paying for overpriced Chinese food.
author: Kelly L.

description: This is mainly for the for the hand pulled Braised Beef Noodle Soup. Everything else is mediocre but I LOVE this soup because the broth is just perfect....savory and rich with the right amount of tang. Spice level is adjustable with the chili sauce floating on the surface.  Most versions are bland and watered down.  Add Chinese pea pod veggies to complete the soup. Have to say was disappointed once when I had the Braised beef with tendon and the tendon was spoiled so ask to see if it is fresh for the day.
author: And H.

description:
Came here with my family for a quick lunch, here's a quick overview of everything.

Food:
- Shanghai dumplings (xiao long bao): Not all of them had "soup" inside them, which is what they're known for. I ate about 4 pieces and only 2 had soup? So I guess that's a 50% rate actually biting into a delicious dumpling and another 50% of a mediocre below average dumpling. Because the soup IS what MAKES this dumpling.

-Spicy beef hand-pulled noodle: The noodles are not hand "pulled" but they are indeed hand made. I can tell because I sat right in front of the chef. The noodles were good and they are 100% hand made! Not even machines were used for mixing the dough. But this had to be my favorite dish. The broth was good and the meat was tender. Portion wasn't lacking and I would definitely recommend this

- Pork dumplings: We wanted pork and chives dumpling but they ran out. So we settled for these. These weren't amazing or anything just okay lol.. 

Service: 
Not attentive. I feel like they are... understaffed. The buslady was constantly rushing around and sometimes tables were left and not cleaned for a long time. I felt bad for her cause she seemed extremely busy and hence lack of attention The host/ server wasn't very attentive either, but she didn't seem like she was busy. We called for our check and she just stood there busy on her phone to even realize it .__.

Environment: 
Overall clean but super small and squished restaurant. Pretty indifferent about this.
author: Jenny N.

description: Where else can you get authentic soup dumplings (xiao long bao) this side of the pacific!? I loved them, and the wantons in chili oil were also fantastic. The price kind of floored me though... that might be because I'm from Canada, and our dollar isn't doing so well. Still it seemed pricey for dumplings and tea.
author: Michael W.

description: Best dumpling house we've found so far! We went to Nanking next door to here the first night craving for some dumplings only to find store bought Costco dumplings. Not listening to hotel concierge anymore for food recommendations!  So glad we came to House of Xian!!! Authentic homemade dumplings!
author: Paren S.

description: Specifically asked the waiter if the shrimp dumplings had pork. They said no. "Shrimp" dumplings arrive loaded with pork. Suddenly they don't speak enough English to exchange my meal or give me a refund. Horrible service. Never going back. Disgusting.
author: August W.

description: Had a good experience with a to-go order. Got the soup dumplings and the Mongolian Beef. Tasty! Used Grubhub and food arrived quickly and fresh. Good option for a quick lunch.
author: Lauren A.

description:
Was open earlier 11am Saturday vs House of Nanking next door so we decided to try it. 
Disappointed in the shrimp and chive dumplings, not much flavor. Used alot of vinegar to try and make do. The cold schredded potatoes were flavorless less the sauce. The fried chicken skewers we also just ok. We had hoped for a chicken teriyaki flavor.
Service slow and we were the only ones there. Suppliers coming in and out taking very loud as if there weren't any customers. Wish we had wai5ed for House of Nanking!
author: Whitney B.

description:
So we read through all the yelp reviews to determine which china town restaurant we were going to go to for our San Francisco trip. We decided to try The house of Xian dumpling.  It is small and very spartan in its ambiance but we were expecting this and it was clean.  It was practically full at 5:30 but my wife and I were able to get a seat near the back.

We ordered the west lamb dumplings, the pork pot stickers, the beef fried rice, and the beef strips in think sauce with noodles.  It was all good but some where better than others.
The beef fried rice came out first and was excellent.  No additional sauces needed.

Then cam the beef strips in think noodle sauce.  It was good but I liked the fried rice better.

The west lamb dumplings came out next and I thought it was a little bland.  They needed some kind of accompanying sauce.
Next was the pork pot stickers. They were also excellent.  My wife said "they are so good, it shows you how we can't find good Chinese food in Texas"

All in all I give them four stars.  But this is because of the food and not the ambiance/presentation.
author: Tim W.

description:
Came here for lunch on a business trip and ordered the beef noodle soup and another order of bok choy thinking that I'd try to be good and eat less of the noodles..I was gravely mistaken.  

The noodles really are made fresh(you can watch them being made in the dining room) and they come in 3 sizes.  I mean't to order the wider noodles but just got the regular house noodles instead but they were still very chewy and tasty.  The beef itself was of decent quality, a lot of other chinese restaurants tend to use beef with lots of tendon or cartilige in their niu rou mien.  The soup had just a tiny bit of spice, I personally wish it had more but the broth was tasty nonetheless and not too salty or oily.  

The bok choy was also good, not over cooked or too heavily sauced.  I went at around 11:30 because I hate waiting so service was quick.  Overall I'd definitely come again, it fits the lunch hour and portions are generous for what you pay.
author: Veronica H.

description: For their take-out it looks like any other place, but to my surprise their beef over rice was absolutely packing to the stomach.  I couldn't believe it.  Nothing but plus marks.
author: BanBan B.

description:
This place is in China Town, small hole in the wall place. 

*** this is a review of the braised beef noodle soup and their pork dumpling only. 

I recommend the braised beef noodle soup (hand pulled noodles),which gives it a home-made taste, and the pork dumplings. I havent found a better place yet who makes better braised noodle soup thus the 5 stars on what they specialize in. The broth is not overwhelming yet very flavorful - a combination of pepper hot sauce, cilantro, bok choi and braised beef. The dumplings are light, fluffy and flavorful, perfect with soy sauce and hot sauce.

They have a person hand pulling noodles so you can see the whole process!
author: Sarah K.

description:
Xian food in SF? What? Rarity! The only places I know of to get Xian Chinese food would be in mainland China and the popular Xi'an Famous Foods in NYC.

Xian region's Chinese food is known for their handpulled noodles & lamb dishes, including their lamb burger. The beef noodle soup here doesn't disappoint. Noodles were soft & full of flavor, the broth was good, and the beef really tender. I was actually hoping they offered stir fry hand pulled noodles instead since that's a more popular dish.

Another popular item, the lamb skewers were pretty good, not the best I've had though but good enough uncommon find.

My biggest gripe is that they don't have the iconic spicy cumin lamb burger that Xian Chinese food is known for, or the lamb pao-mo soup. These are supposed to be staples!!

Being located on the border of Chinatown & North Beach, it seems like most of the menu is catered to tourists who don't know the difference in regional food so those who drop by ordering dim sum are probably in for a mediocre time. Order correctly!

Service was okay, speaking in Chinese means bonus points I guess.
author: Steven C.

description: Soup dumplings we're about $9 and was decent. I was very disappointed in the scallion pancakes though. Not worth getting!
author: Amy L.

description: I am a regular customer at House of Xian Dumpling, and am a big fan of their food.  I've tried all the pork, shrimp, and fish dumplings (with various combinations of chives and cabbage) and all of them are very tasty. The beef tendon soup and the braised beef noodle soup are also very tasty and spicy, and are the hand pulled noodles are nice and chewy.  The cold spicy beef tendon and also the shredded pig ears are also very tasty appetizers.  The only real downside is that the service is sometimes a bit slow, and the portions are a bit on the small side, however they're always very friendly, and the northern chinese food is quite a bit different than the neighboring Cantonese and Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Allen T.

description:
Clean location albeit very TIGHT.

I found the female manager very friendly and nice.

Hand Pulled Noodle Soup with beef ball, seaweed, shrimp and BBQ pork ($7.95) - liked the seaweed.

Braised Beef Noodle Soup ($6.95). It was supposed to be spciy, but it wasn't too hot - no sweating  - whew!

Boiled Cabbage and Pork Dumpling ($6.95)...I want to eat more :)

What we tried were good and priced reasonably!

Give it a try - it's better than next door(s) (Left) waiting in line for bad service or (right) paying for a happy ending! :P
author: Peter L.

description: This place serves a really rare and hard to find Chinese dish - hand-pulled noodles served in a bowl full of spicy oil. Mix it up and slurp it down. You'll definitely need a shower after but it's totally worth it.
author: Grayson K.

description:
House of Xian Dumpling had a line last time we passed. so my SO wanted to try it. she heard the food was cheap.  i told her i heard the food was garbage.

eats:
-shanghai pan fried pork bun (6/6.95)
skin texture good, innards fill with fat and old meat, tasted funny
*SO left all the meat on the plate, didn't want to get sick. just ate the skin
-xiao long bao (8/6.95)
filled with fatty soup, filling had funny tasting meats, lots of fat. left on plate
-braised beef tendon noodle soup (6.95)
hand pull noodles? maybe, not much noodle
tender tendons, lean beef, not that many, few veggies
broth filled with salt/soy  and msg, sipped just a little, left the rest
.1,5 stars

crumbs:
-food not so clean, small portions, thus pricey
-noticed deliveries of premade frozen xiao lung bao's/potstickers in plastic bags while we were eating.
-eating all the fatty meats, msg would probably have led to a stroke if i wasn't already taking lipitor.....food is unhealthy here, do u feel lucky?
-service just ok. no checkins.
author: Victor G.

description:
There is nothing with Xian
这里和西安的美食毫无关系，纯粹是挂羊头卖狗肉的噱头。

The waitress is rude.
这里的服务员想当的粗鲁无礼，把中国礼仪之邦的脸都给丢尽了。

 They even tell a 60-year-old couple to GET OUT without a reason.It`s unbelievable!
她们甚至毫无理由的叫一对六十岁的夫妇滚蛋。不可理喻！

Terrible food, awful waitress, unbelievable price.If you want those ,there is your NO.1 choose
不地道的食物，恶劣糟糕粗俗的女服务员，不能接受的离谱的价格。如果你想去一家世上最烂的餐馆，这里是你最好的选择。
author: Danyang L.

description:
Beware - they don't have actual hand-pulled noodles any more, despite what the sign and menu says.  The edges are perfectly smooth and sharply cut - clearly not hand pulled.  And they aren't even very good noodles.  

The dumplings were pretty good though.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Small place with a man in a cart hand pulling noodles. 

Highly recommend:
- the braised beef noodle soup (sooo delicious, noodles are a perfect texture, the broth is so tasty, and the beef is so soft!)
- the steamed pork and chive dumplings (one order is 12 dumplings!)
- the grilled lamb skewers (well-spiced and piping hot)
- the hot soy milk

Was not impressed with the soup dumplings here - they did not taste fresh and were very small. 

Super fast service.
author: Amelia C.

description: So so Sooo sad that the quality has gone down ): Always a mandatory spot to eat at when we visit SF and we are pretty disappointed it no longer lives up to its previous amazingness. The server was one we'd never seen before and she wasn't friendly at all. Seemed like it was a hassle anytime we asked her for anything. Literally the only time she smiled at us is when we handed her our card to pay. THEY DIDNT HAVE SATÉ/CHILI OIL ANYMORE!! What soup dumpling place doesn't have that? More than half of our soup dumplings were not soupy, there isn't as much flavor in the house special chow mein anymore, & the potsticker skin was thicker which made it too doughy and not so great. Sighhh.
author: Adrienne V.

description: Delicious beef noodle soup, chow mein and spring rolls! A hidden gem, not much of a wait, super friendly servers!
author: Cathy P.

description: Portion size of the veggies here weren't great (we got the pea sprouts) but the prices were pretty cheap. The dumplings were good and most people get the beef noodle soup with the house made dumplings. The soup is under 7 which makes the meal end up being pretty cheap and getting a bowl of it yourself will definitely fill you up. This place is probably not good for groups over 6.
author: Lily P.

description: I love how things taste here. Great broth, tasty tender beef, awesome noodles, fabulous hot sauce. Health rating warning a bit scary, but I haven't gotten sick yet, and so tasty. Oh, and boiled sesame mochi desert, so umami!
author: Pai-Ling Y.

description:
Pros:
It's in a good location and the service is somewhat good.

Cons:
It's very small inside to be a sit down restaurant and it's right next door to better restaurants.

Food Experience:
We came here because the restaurant next door was full and the wait was much to long so we had to settle for this one. It was simply okay, nothing truly special. I was surprise to see alot of people here. I was still hungry after I ate my Pho large soup. 

Conclusion:
I wouldn't really bother unless you're starving and all other restaurants in Chinatown are just closed.
author: Irving B.

description:
I'm Asian, but I don't really like SF's Chinatown all that much (I prefer Oakland's Chinatown).  But today I had to take a trip to Asian Law Caucus, so I decided to reward myself with a noodle house afterward. 

I am *so* happy to have stumbled upon this place.  I got the braised beef with hand-pulled flat noodles.  The broth was rich and warming-but-not-spicyhot, and the beef was the most tender I've ever had.  I barely had to chew it. I'm definitely going back and I'm getting the exact same thing. 

Every table was full, but the service was quick, and they staff was friendlier and more pleasant than is usual for a Chinese restaurant.
author: A K.

description: Just got takeout from this place, dumplings and noodle soup.  Best dumplings I've had in ages.  Very tasty hand-pulled noodles in the soup and a satisfying complex broth.  Great prices.  Why wait in line for House of Nanking next door when you can get fresh delicious food from the nice ladies at House of  Xian?
author: Michelle C.

description: This place is awesome with super tasty food and no worry if unfamiliar with noodles and dumplings....very friendly staff helps with menu selection...great find!
author: Chuck B.

description: Never in my life have I seen an 18% service charge for a party of two. I would not take my worst enemy here unless he was paying. If I could give 0 stars, I would.
author: Damian F.

description: I really like to get a bow of hand pulled noodles soup (beef) and some dumplings. If its just me eating them I leave hating myself cause I'm so full. Usually runs about $17 w/ soup and dumplings.
author: Mike G.

description: Food is really not delicious.  18% tip is mandatory even for small parties.  Service is ok tho.
author: Wan Z.

description:
Oh dear lord how I love this place. Tiny little space, too many people, dude in a pope-mobile style booth making the hand pulled noodles...  It was so busy but the service was fast and our waitress was very helpful.

We ordered way too much food, then we ordered some more.  Seriously, there were three of us and we ordered the soup dumplings a green onion pancake, two different bowls of soup (beef noodle and chicken with corn and chicken dumplings,) pork buns, Chinese broccoli and lamb skewers. When we were all done with that, we ordered another order of the soup dumplings because I had to have more.  I can't get them that good here in DFW so I wanted to make myself tired of them. It didn't work, I'm craving them again already.
author: Susan F.

description: Soup dumpling had nice, soft thin skin. But zero flavor in the filling. Also not that much soup. Great execution on the most common complaint on soup dumplings - thick skin.  but the heart and soul of the dumplings was missing. It was like eating a matzoh ball for the filling. Beef tendon appetizer was not to my palette. Super salty and too stringy and the flavor combinations were too strange for me. I think I need to stick to non-northern Chinese. Not for the newbie palette.
author: Catherine L.

description:
The food is awesome! Everything my family ordered was up to par with our experienced taste buds. 

We ordered the lamb skewers and spicy beef tendon for our appetizers. The lamb was marinated with all the right spices and they weren't dry or burnt. The beef tendon dish had a great flavor as well as a big kick from the chili. 
We ordered the xiao long bao, which was the best I've had in a while. These are excellent. You know it's good when you're able to pick it up with chopsticks without the skin puncturing and when you bite into it and you get a burst of soupy goodness. We also ordered the shanghai panfried pork bun, and let me tell you, the skin was not too thick and had a great crunch. The pork was nicely seasoned as well. Next we had the hand pulled beef noodle soup. The soup tasted great, msg free and made from hours of stewing beef bones. The hand pulled noodles were also nice, not too soft and they had a good chewiness to it. There's also two sizes of these noodles: thick or thin. The pork and chive dumplings were piping hot and pretty good, don't let them cool down before you finish it otherwise your taste buds will be mad at you! The skin is a little more thick than I would've liked, but at least they don't tear on you when you pick it up!
The waitress is also super funny and nice. The seating is a bit cramped but it is Chinatown!

Overall, the food is great and flavorful, the price is decent, and the staff is friendly. I would definitely come back again because their xiao long baos are BOMB.
author: Eva C.

description:
A great find in Chinatown! The food is authentic, well-portioned & priced, and the service is great. I was excited to see the red bean paste pancake on the menu, but it didn't live up to expectations.

Recommended: Beef Noodle Soup, Pea Sprouts
author: Linda X.

description: Ordered from here after I finally ran out of late-night takeout spots to choose from while I'm working late in Fidi. Probably wouldn't order again though... Dumplings were as good as advertised but the beef noodle soup was given to me in a to-go container that doesn't allow me to actually EAT the soup without pouring it in a separate container or bowl (which I only have at home). So much for that.
author: Brian S.

description: Enjoyed the pork buns. The soup dumplings were ok but seemed like maybe they were frozen? The veggie gyoza were ok too. Nothing amazing but good enough and reasonably priced.
author: Gemma Z.

description:
did not experience the service issues that others complained about.
I did feel that the food was pretty tasteless (ordered 3 types of dumplings that we indistinguishable from each other).
Also, pretty pricey for what it was, $75 with tip for two people at lunch.  Granted, I think we probably ordered one dish too many, but still,that is kind of high for lunch.  they also charged $2 per person for tea, which i have never experienced before in a Chinese restaurant.
author: alex m.

description: FANTASTIC!! Soup dumplings, green onion pancake, Dan Dan noodles were superb. Best hole in the wall dumpling spot we have found!!
author: Sherri B.

description:
Good: braised beef noodle soup. The bowl is huge so you think there's a ton of food, but actually only 4 or 5 pieces of beef slices. I did like the noodles, and the broth was savory.

Eh: west lake lamb dumplings. I had really high hopes for this one but it fell flat, you couldn't really tell the lamb taste.

Next time I would try: lamb skewers, to give this place another chance.

Service was totally fine.
author: Mary X.

description: This restaurant is so americandised, not Xi'an food at all. All the waitresses are from Guangdong. So disappointed. Even the spicy sauce is some kind of sauce we can buy from Vietnamese supermarket. Cannot be even compared to homemade food... Not recommended to Chinese from North China.
author: Xin G.

description: This place DUPES customers of their money. Only go if you don't mind getting TRICKED in your bill. This place serves decent food and service but DECEIVES customers by (1) charging a MANDATORY TIP of 18% under the hoax of service charge thinking the customer is a fool (2) they then tax you (@ 8.75%) not only for the food but for the exorbitant tip you didn't even know you are being charged, like who does this BS!!!! I was shocked to see this and told the waitress this was wrong, but in response shamelessly she replied our machine has an issue and we will get it fixed (of course, after we have screwed all our customers). The best was yet to come :( After charging my card these folks had the audacity to bring me a receipt asking for a TIP, I was like OMG, these guys are so F**k'in GREEDY. The sad part is I saw so many folks falling to this trap and paying a TIP on top of the involuntarily 18% TIP they unknowingly have already paid.  PLEASE DON'T GO THERE, PERIOD!
author: Rishabh J.

description: Some of the most fantastic food, and the best Chinese food that I've had yet.  I'm told it's very authentic too, not that over-sugared Americanized nonsense.
author: Keane D.

description: Excellent dumplings & potstickers. Very authentic, clean & friendly staff.   Large portions for the price.
author: Shannon C.

description:
We loved this place!  So sooooo much better than House Of Nanking. 

We had the braised beef noodle soup. Shanghai soup dumplings and an order of beef fried rice. All were good and the portions were large. The prices were reasonable, at least similar to other Chinatown restaurants. The place was packed at noon on a weekday. All happy diners with not a single table empty. They were also filling huge take out orders. This place was busy. 

The formula is simple. Good food at a reasonable price. How hard is that?" This place fills the bill. Stop by and have a bite. It is an enjoyable experience.
author: Steven G.

description:
Despite the low Yelp reviews, I had high hopes for this restaurant. I'm pretty familiar with Chinese service, and I had my expectations set quite low. However, this restaurant was beyond saving...I'm being generous with two stars, because they had a guy making hand-pulled noodles live on the spot, which was pretty neat. It's not too often you get to see that first-hand. 

When I walked in on a weekday lunch hour, the place was actually pretty packed. There were no tables available, except next to a woman who was sitting and waiting for her takeout order. That was fine by me. I learned that she had already been waiting ten minutes or so for her takeout. She didn't receive her food until a good ten minutes later, after I placed my order. That's pretty ridiculous for just getting takeout chinese if you ask me. there was nothing really complex about cooking this food -- most of it was steamed or fried. I ended up waiting about 20 minutes for my food as well. I can't believe they've been open for months and they still don't have their cooking line in order. 

All I ordered was dumpling noodle soup...how could it have taken 20 minutes to make? Anyway the broth was completely flavorless. It just tasted like water, which it probably was. At least I have the comfort of knowing they didn't add MSG. However, as a restaurant, I'd expect them to take the taste of their food more seriously than that. The dumplings tasted pretty good though, and I'd imagine the spicy soup would have gone well with, and pan-fried dumplings wouldn't have been bad either. Just don't order the plain soup (it's just water)! 

Just keep in mind that they take their own sweet time cooking the food during rush hour, so don't come here if you're in a rush.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Summer never seems to hit in SF. It's the middle of June and I'm still freezing my ass off in sub-60 degree weather. It's on those days that I'm looking for a warm broth that hits the spot!

And that's what House of Xian Dumpling does for me. They have some of the best Beef Noodle Soup in town. From the hand pulled noodles to the perfectly tender beef, you can't go wrong with it if you're looking to channel your inner Chinese appetite! 

I will say, however, that I was a bit disappointed with the soup dumplings. They weren't as soupy as I had hoped, and I didn't like that they gave me the soy sauce and vinegar pre-mixed, whereas most xiao long bao places I've been to allow you to mix it to your own preference.
author: Kenneth S.

description: The chive, pork and shrimp dumplings with soy, vinegar, and hot sauce are delicious. The chili oil wontons are excellent the place is very busy during lunch time so plan consider take-out as well.
author: N A.

description: Small portions and way overpriced.  Got the noodle soup which tasted fine, good noodles and good broth too but for 9.95$ it was way overpriced for the small bowl.  There are lots of good, cheap places within a block of Xian so try one of them.
author: Bill S.

description:
Beef noodle: broth not beefy, not much beef, two things of bok choy, sad amount of noodles compared to amount of mediocre broth, and spiciness was just some other hot sauce/chili oil dumped in

Shanghai pan fried dumpling: thick dry bland bun, unjuicy bland meat filling. Terrible 

Boiled cabbage & pork dumpling: same crappy meat filling, skin a little too thick for my taste (although that might just be the style)
author: Jeffry C.

description:
Maybe today was my unlucky day. I went to house of xian dumplings to finally try their famous beef noodle soup. Me and my sister both ordered their beef noodle soup, a plate of green onion pancakes (they were out of the five spice pancake which we wanted to try), a plate of their pan fried shanghai dumplings, and a plate of steamed buns.

It was pretty packed on a monday at 1pm, probably because its still lunch time. But we were lucky to get a seat. We saw the people who also ordered a noodle soup got their food pretty fast. We got our green onion pancake, steamed buns and pan fried shanghai dumplings in a timely manner.

The green onion pancakes: it was pretty dry and bland. Would not recommend! 

The steamed buns: its was ok, nothing special. I was probably stupid to ordered that when theres a lot of steamed buns in chinatown for cheaper. 

The pan fried shanghai dumplings: this disappointed me the most. There was no soup in it! It was so dry. I ordered this the last time I came here and it was good (there was soup inside). 

O wait! My review for the beef noodle soup? I cant rate it because we never received it. We were close to finishing our other dishes. And we noticed new customers who came in after us got their beef noodle soup, finished eating it AND paid their bill and left already. We just decided to pay our bill and leave because we thought maybe they forgot about it and we dont want to wait anymore. We didnt finished our other stuff so we asked for boxes. 

When we got our bill, they sure DID NOT forget to charge us for the 2 beef noodle soup. So i told them we never received it (so we're not paying for that). The lady who looks like shes in charge apologized, took the bill back and told the kitchen to make our noodle soup. I was surprised that they thought we still want the noodles after we already boxed our leftovers and was looking like we're ready to leave. So i told them we dont want it anymore. They apologized and gave us our adjusted bill.

I noticed a 10 cents charge for a bag which i didnt ask for. I didnt want to make a big deal for 10 cents so I just sucked it in and paid. But the nerve, wow. The total was 15 something which I didnt think was worth it. I still left them $1 tip because at least they apologized. But the way they do business (forgot our order, made us wait and charged us for a bag when I only asked for boxes), i dont think ill be back. I was really looking forward to try their beef noodle soup but I dont think I will ever know how that taste like.
author: Mandy Y.

description:
Staying in the Financial District, it was literally impossible to find a place to eat past 7:00 PM unless your idea of dinner is a Subway foot long. Walked a few blocks from our hotel into China Town and stumbled into this place by chance. Remembering a dumpling feast I was served in Xian, China, this seemed a good idea as any.

The owner/ manager was very friendly and speaks perfect English. This is a hole in the wall, very casual, the prices are cheap and they do take credit cards, if I recall correctly. 

The shrimp and chive dumplings were just okay. While they were fresh, the wrappers were too thick for my liking and the chives overpowering. 

Be sure to order some of the scallion pancakes. The dough is basically wheat flour and water, lightly seasoned, sprinkled with chopped scallions, brushed with sesame oil, rolled out flat, folded over, brushed again and so forth. The result is somewhere between phyllo and pizza dough, deep dried. Delicious. 

The vegetable fried rice is a huge portion and enough to feed a family of four. It was very flavorful and difficult to stop eating it. I wish they had a brown rice version.

The red bean filled pancake is a simple and yummy dessert. Same concept as described above, except sweet. I was very full but this was too good not to finish. I would totally come here just for these pancakes. Mental note: Make these back at home.
author: Ute L.

description: This was the first place we ventured into as we strolled into Chinatown. The pork and cabbage soup dumplings were amazing. In my humble opinion, the perfect ratio of wrapper and meat, which is a gamechanger in the dumpling street game.  These soup dumplings have major street cred; it's worth a trip just to try them.  The salt and pepper chicken wings were decent, nothing special. I have another day left here in SF, and I might have to grab a dozen (or 2) for the road...
author: Mike R.

description:
Much better service this second time around, though it might be due to the owner not being around. The waitress was attentive and nice, and the food was rocking like last time.

For dinner for three, we got the cold pig ears, Shanghai soup dumplings, Westlake beef dumplings, and the lamb & chives dumplings. The flavorings are a little more muted than Kingdom of Dumpling, but still nicely done. Pig ears were great, so don't knock 'em until you try 'em.
author: Kevin L.

description:
After reading most of the reviews, i thought i'd be prepared for my experiences at House of Xian Dumpling but i was still really disappointed!

1. i read that they were out of a lot of items on their menu but i thought it'd help that we went for lunch. but during lunch, they were out of XLBs, all skewer items and chives. i mean, CHIVES?! 

2. operationally, the place was a mess. there were 2 or 3 parties waiting outside for a table with many tables vacant. but the staff couldn't/didn't clean up in time so that people can sit down. They allowed someone who was waiting for take out to utilize a table while other people waited outside?!

3. they forgot one of our items that we had to order because they were out of everything.

4. the item came with a hair on it - gross.
author: Terry C.

description:
We were on the way to grab lunch in North Beach when we peered in and were tempted by people wolfing down dumplings and noodle soups. 

The dumplings are hand-made, and I assume fresh since it took a while. I loved the corn and chicken dumplings we ordered. Corn always adds a unique texture. The skin used for their dumplings is on the thicker side. 
The Xiao Long Bao was delicious.
author: Sharon H.

description: The food is okay. But I don't like the fact that they add 18% service charge for any number of guests, without telling anyone. Then when you get the credit card receipt there is another line for tip. Seems like doing this intentionally without telling anyone is shady.
author: Kevin H.

description: Worst experience in sf. Charged 18% tip automatically without consent and notification. Nothing close to authentic Xian food.
author: Yangzi Z.

description:
The food is not authentic. Service is disappointing. This small restaurant pays no attention to hygiene. We ordered pork and chive dumplings to go, and they packed the boiling hot dumplings into a plastic box with soy sauce packets! 

How could they put the food and the sauce packets in the same box? And when they had paper to-go boxes, they chose to pack the burning hot food with plastic ones! 

We asked a waitress to give us a paper to-go box instead, and she did. She gave us a DUSTY paper box! That's unbelievable! After being told, the waitress took that dusty box back and used a dish cloth that she used to clean the table to wipe dust out. Then, she put it back to the shelf, and gave us another to-go box.

It's hard to imagine what kind of hygienic conditions they have in the kitchen. Definitely won't visit again!
author: Sylvia H.

description: After they're change a new owner, they did charge 18% service charge even we had two people, and also charge us two dollars for green tea each person, we did ask for regular free tea！When we're asked them reason why？They'd automated took out those charges without any explanation, I'm lucky because I did check my bill, what about you？
author: ian k.

description: Really bad food. If you are looking for northern Chinese flavor, DON't GO!! They said they are Xian flavor, actually everything is extremely sweet. It's not Cantonese not Xian and not good at all! We went there about 6:30, almost every restaurant lined up with more than 20 people, but this one was pretty empty. It's because it's really BAD!! And they add 18% gratuity automatically, but they don't deserve it at all!!
author: Kyna X.

description:
Food was excellent.

Loved it all. Cucumber salad with peanuts- this was julienned cucumbers with a spicy oil and boiled peanuts. We couldn't stop eating it.

Xiao long bao- yum. The dumpling skin was not too think nor too thin. The meat inside was so juicy and perfect with the vinegar sauce it came with. Almost tasted a little sweet.

Braised beef noodle soup- these noodles were not actually hand pulled as the sign says, but is instead rolled and cut into strips. They weren't too thick like other places and soup had amazing flavor.

I would come back in a heartbeat!
author: Heidi L.

description:
A small but nice restaurant with authentic noodles and dumplings! Best I've ever had in the city. Definitely worth a try!

We ordered Noodle with beef, which is a little bit spicy but tastes awesome.
author: Sarah Z.

description: Went there on a Monday night with some friends, service was quick and people were friendly. Food was average, I think the pork dumplings' dough was a bit thick and chewy. The noodles were great though. Pricing was great, among 5 people it was $10 each. Being a foreigner, I am very thankful that gratuity was included
author: Emily S.

description: This is one of my favourite place for dumpling! Actually I never try another dumpling from another place because I ok with this restaurant and not far from my place lol . I like cabbage and pork dumpling very much. It is tasty and juicy. The beef Chow Mian is good too. The taste of the fired noodle with beef are perfect for me. Another dish that I like is lotus root salad. Fresh chopped lotus root mixed with vinegar, soy sauce and sesame oil.
author: Orange S.

description: Great local spot. Can't go wrong with anything here. My personal favorites include the beef noodle soup, beef pancake, Chinese broccoli, and chicken and corn dumplings. Great for take-out too!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
UPDATE:  Just confirmed with the waitress, the noodle chef no longer works for the restaurant.  Still pissed that they decided to blatantly lie about substituting with store-bought noodle as if we patrons are idiots and do not know better.



This place has been my go to beef noodle soup place since it opened last year.  However, on my visit today, the noodles are no longer hand made, replaced with flaccid, perfectly cut machine manufactured noodle you buy from the market instead.  Adding insult to injury, the waitress insisted that they are hand pulled when I asked.  The broth also tasted watered down.  Should have gotten the hint when I didn't see the noodle chef that's usually out on the floor on weekdays.  Pity...I liked this place too...
author: Kayes C.

description:
Pros:
- Super cheap
- Pretty delicious dumplings
- Beef noodles also worth a try. Lots of flavor
- If you're looking for a divey kinda place with good food, cheap prices, and a quick in/out experience, this is actually a really great place

Cons:
- Service is so-so. I don't really care about that though.
author: Doug G.

description:
This place is alright. It might be good compared to what's available around the area, but I've definitely had better. 

Overall thoughts: The xiao long bao's were good, but not the best. The pan fried dumplings were a downer. The service was attentive though, much better then the standard Chinatown hospitality. I wouldn't say 'no' to eating here again, but I wouldn't be racing to the door either.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Very expensive for a below average quality. Don't go there. Ended up trashing the food because it was so bad. Also had to wait 15 min for a to go order.
author: Baptiste P.

description:
I waited 35 minutes after ordering for a bowl of not very impressive noodle, when they finally served it, my wife had already finished her food. I was unhappy about their service, so only tipped 10%. However after I signed the bill, on a second look at the list, I found they clearly had already add 18% tips just for the two of us, without giving any notice. Also a waitress stayed behind me and kept looking at me signing the bill somehow. Bathroom door does not lock, some guy opened the door while I was in it.

Not a great experience.
author: Rui Z.

description: The worst Chinese food I have ever eaten. The worst service I have ever received in my life! The service is too too too slow and extremely rude. They basically do not even care to have good customer service. I waited for a dish of dumpling for approximately 2 hours!! YES 2 HOURS!! And when it finally arrived, it did not have any taste & I am very sure they have just used frozen dumplings. I have eaten dumplings in various restaurants & I can tell you their dumpling was the worst I have ever had. But the worst part does not even end here. Of course I did not put any tips for them. Because tip is for the service & when the service is extremely rude and slow, why in the world I would put tips ? It is just like giving them money and thanking them for being rude to me !! I checked my back statement & realized that they have charged me 18% for the tip that I have never putted WITHOUT MY KNOWLEDGE. It is ILLEGAL & of course I reported them to BBB !! There are plenty good restaurants in the area. Do not waste your time and money to come here.
author: Niyayesh K.

description: MMMMmmmmmMmmm. Great place to eat if you want to get away for the crazy expensive and crowded places near Union square. I highly recommend the noodle soup. They are SO flavorful... Tastes of 5 spice and something sweet :o. I got the tendon and it is a bit spicy but oh sooo good. The noodles are al dente as well!
author: Lisa T.

description:
Bad customer service. We seated ourselves since no one bothered to seat us. 

Otherwise the chicken chow mein is worthwhile.  They hand make their noodles and it shows! It's pretty delicious, one order can feed 2 to 3 people.

We also ordered shrimp and chives dumplings. It was more chives than shrimp,  you couldn't even taste the shrimp.
author: Fatimah Z.

description:
Was here on a Sunday for late lunch so no wait and were seated right away. Their menu is typical of the dumpling places I love in Parkside/Outer Sunset (Kingdom of Dumpling, House of Pancakes, etc.) But bonus because they are located much closer to me in Chinatown. I've always avoided Chinatown because when I was a tourist visiting I had the worst food somewhere there. I am now  finding better places to eat there as a local.

We had:
- XLB (xiao long bao) .. good but not as much soup as the other places mentioned
- chicken skewers.. good
- lamb dumplings.. good and I agree that they're thicker than others
- fried tofu with chili sauce... my favorite.. soo soo good
- beef pancake.. good but again, not as good as the other places

Overall I think this place is great. I keep comparing it to my favorites but that's good because they are able to keep up on most items. Service was really fast and efficient, friendly even. We'll definitely be back.
author: Vol T.

description:
Nothing amazing here... We were touring China town and walked by this small little dumpling place. It seemed small yet crowded so we decided to give it a try. Small is a bit of understatement... The tables are so close to each other it should be a fire hazard.  We ordered some shrimp with leek dumplings, pancake with beef, and a chinese broccoli dish. The dumpling was underwhelming... We can barely taste the smooshed up shrimp. The pancake on the pancake with beef was thick and the beef was underwhelming and oily. The broccoli with oyster sauce is the only decent dish.

Pros: edible.

Con: crammed. Oily. Fillings for the pancake with beef and dumpling is underwhelming.
author: Jamie L.

description: I can't say enough about this place!!!!  So yummy. We came across it on our recent visit and it is one of the best I've eaten.  We search for soup dumplings in every major city and these were fantastic.
author: Lisa P.

description:
Don't let the tourist lure of House of Nanking sway you from this small nondescript Chinese food place! Filling in for the now-gone Chef Jia's, House of Xian Dumpling has a range of appetizers, dim sums, and entrees. We decided to order a few different appetizers and dim sums for dinner: pork potstickers, veggie potstickers, green onion pancakes and honey chili tofu. We had more than enough food to fill the two of us easily and it wound up being only $20 for the whole thing. 

The surprising winner of the night was the tofu though. Fried tofu cubes with sweet chili sauce on top, it seemed simple and rather boring, but instead was delicious and crispy and amazing. I think I ate almost the entire plate. The potstickers were also a hit and the green onion pancakes were great for picking up leftover sauces.

If you're looking for quick, cheap, good Chinese food, come here for it instead of next door. You shouldn't be disappointed.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
We had a very nice meal this evening. My husband had Kung pao chicken, middle temp. I had the pan fried pork buns and my 9 year old had pork and chive dumplings. We all shared the hot and sour soup. All the food was good,
I'm not an expert in this cuisine but eat out a lot. Certainly better than waiting in line for the place next door. My daughter is a very picky eater and she loved it. Service was attentive. A non fancy spot but solid.
author: Leslie F.

description: Amazing homemade dumplings on the outskirts of China town. Very quaint w excellent service. That did well to accommodate my family of 5.  Everything from the dumplings, fried rice and hot and sour soup were top notch. Would come here again in a heartbeat!
author: Steve S.

description:
Shanghai dumplings is 4/5.  The cabbage and pork dumpling is fresh but can use more seasoning. 3/5 for us.   We also tried the beef pancake. This one is pretty yummy but the beef filling is scarce.  

We also ordered the assorted beef balls soup noodle.  3/5 for the soup noodle.  I've read the spicy beef tendon noodle soup is better so i may try that next time.
author: Dodo K.

description:
If you ate authentic Xian cuisine before, then you won't think this place is all that great.  They do have a lot of the Xian dishes but it's not great.  It's decent for those that haven't eat the real stuff before.  

The store is very small so it can't accommodate much people.  Service is minimal but they charge 18% for tips automatically on your bill and it's not disclosed on the menu.  We only had a party of 4.  It's ridiculous!  Don't like this style of charging for no service.  Definitely wouldn't come back.
author: Daniel T.

description:
Chicken fried rice : chicken was well cooked, flavorful, and not stale at all like at most chinese places. House chicken chilli noodle soup - so amazinggg!!! I would come back just for this soup.
chicken skewer: well cooked with spices. Really loved it.
chicken and corn dumplings: was okay
pork dumpling in chilli oil: nothing great about this one.
I'm coming back again.
author: I Love Good Foo D.

description: Beef noodle soup was too sweet. Braised beef appetizer was literally 8 slice. Overall a very average place for Asian restaurant standard in San Francisco.
author: Jensen K.

description: I love this place!!!! Cabbage pork dumplings are so great. Very fresh. And beef pancake is delicious too. Lamb skewers are not exactly like Chinese one. But still very good!!!! De finely come back!!! The lady who works there is super nice!!! Really nice service.
author: Emma C.

description: Noodle soups are fantastic and the soup dumplings are everything you ask for. Also, very friendly service.
author: Kristie B.

description: We were looking for authentic hand-pulled noodles as awesome as the ones in Brooklyn New York but haven't found one in San Francisco that compares
author: Monkey P.

description: Super affordable Chinese eatery located in Kearney Street & Columbus Avenue. Front of house not necessary or existent as it's also a take out. The place is just a single rectangular dining room with 12-14 tables tops.  Choose the appetizing grilled lamb skewers, a 9/10 treat.
