As I was rather hungry I went through 2 main courses (nobody is perfect, eh) the corn & chicken dumplings followed by the cabbage and chicken ones until my hypothalamus finally got (and passed) the message. Delicious food, indeed. Service was adequate (it helps if you speak some Mandarin to communicate) and efficient. No Wi-Fi at the moment. Ah...and the tea is on the house...
author: Pablo D.

description: The shrimp and pork dumplings tasted the same.  Pretty thick skin.  They don't have Chinese mustard.
author: Pasha G.

description:
One word! SHADY. 

I'd give them no stars if I could. It took us 20 minutes to be seating because they wouldn't clear tables. Then it took us at least 2 hours to eat. Getting menus, drinks, ordering, getting food all took an excessive amount of time!!! EXCESSIVE. One table was turned over 3 times in the time that we were there with the same amount of guests. Extremely unorganized. Then when we left they ran out after us because they forgot to swipe our card! When they came back with the card, because they didn't like their 10% tip for bad service, they had added an extra 25% service charge to our bill! So shady. We were so upset we drove all the way back to correct it just because of how bad the service was. The food is fine, House of Nan King is 200 times better next door.
author: Liz F.

description:
Lier! All dumplings were machine made and previously frozen for a long time! 
Charged me 18% service fee without notice!
author: Patrick L.

description:
Ever since Will left Philly and became royalty in California, FRESH has become a thing. Young moms and bearded dudes pine for farm FRESH anything - eggs, veggies, shampoo. Shoeheads will never stop amassing FRESH kicks. Coffee shops are always on the lookout for FRESH wallpaper prints.

However, all this focus needs to be redirected immediately to House of Xian Dumpling's FRESH NOODLES.

The Beef Noodle Soup that houses these pliable strands is spice bombed with potent flavor. The high profile chili invasion exercises restraint in providing the broth with a gradual warm buildup and refrains from being overly salty. The square-cut pieces of beef that usually portend a jaw workout are instead wonderfully tender - not quite at a melting point but still delightfully delicate. The medium-width noodles are noticeably springy, characteristic not only of its freshness but of the chef's pursuit of al dente. After bite upon vibrant bite over the course of half an hour, these hardy noodles do not lose any vitality and ensure quality to the last slurp.

The Salt & Pepper Chicken Wings are less revolutionary but still admirable for its effort. The juicy interior is sealed with flavor and piping hot, but the expected outer crispiness is simply absent. Whether due to temperatures that are not high enough or oil oversaturation, the wings fall short of complete satisfaction.

The service is extremely pleasant and unusually attentive for a Chinese restaurant, much less one in busy Chinatown. Note that there is a $15 minimum for credit cards.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Hole in the wall.
Cheap.
Fast service.
Satisfies the hunger pangs.

Literally it's fast, cheap, and good.  A fan of the beef tendon soup, black fungus, pig ear, veggies, and Shanghai dumplings.
author: Dorothy L.

description: The supposedly hand made noodles tasted like packages noodles. We were't crazy about the broth either. The handmade pan fried bun were good.
author: Ngoclinh R.

description: This is a tourist review since I was just visiting for the weekend. Get the dumplings their known for and you won't be disappointed. My husband and I also tried the noodle soups and while good- they don't compare to their dumplings.
author: Melissa D.

description: Great dumplings, straight forward Chinese restaurant. Been here twice so far and I love it. It's a no bullshit restaurant, nothing fancy, just straight up good Chinese food. They handmake their dumplings every day.
author: Rasmus E.

description: The soup dumplings were on point! We randomly found this place on Yelp and I was worried because generally speaking I think SF Taiwanese food is so so. But the dumplings had a lot of flavor (although skin is a bit thick), the beef noodle soup was pretty tasty (although a bit watered down), and the beef pancakes were delish! I would definitely come back :)
author: Christina C.

description:
I was also surprised to only see 2 1/2 stars. It will probably increase as the months go on. At last, a real "mainland China" restaurant that reminds me of the year I lived in Beijing! The beef noodle soup and the dumplings are authentic, with the noodles all freshly made (you could see the cook hand pulling the noodles). And the service is surprisingly friendly, which is saying a lot for a Chinatown restaurant.  Will be back to explore the other options...

Update, 3 months later:

So glad to know more stars have been added for this restaurant. The restaurant has been busy, particularly during lunch hours. But the turnover seems to be fast.
author: Randy M.

description: The noodles taste bad，over cooked. Dumlping taste same as instant frozen dumplings. And they even charged me 18% tips at noon without inform in advance.
author: Vicky F.

description:
The manager tried to take advantage of me when I tried to pay a 7.56 meal with a debit card. I only had 8 cash with me. When I came in,  I asked the server if I could pay with a debit card,  server said yes.  My bad that I didn't confirm that if there is a minimum amount of purchase. 

When I checked, manager said my 8 dollors was not enough,  almost blocked my way out, I felt uncomfotable. She asked me how much tip I wanted to give,  if it's okay to charge me $10.

Won't go to this place again. Even though I like the food.
author: Tsung Han L.

description: Really bad dumplings.  Thick thick skin that's unpleasant to chew and tiny amount of fillings inside.  Recommend that you try the chive and shrimp dumplings from San Tung.
author: Stacy D.

description:
This place has no business of calling itself Xi'an Dumpling, as any people who have actually visited Xi'an will attest this place is no where even close to the real deal. No Lamb soup? No pulled pork bun? REALLY?? Nevertheless, considering the fact it is an ocean away from Xi'an, ok, I will cut some slacks. 

We first asked for ice water, and one of the glasses was filled with suspicious looking foam; probably from dish detergent. How can anyone screw up ice water? Little did we know, it was actually the high point of our experience, as things will spiral downhill even from an already pretty low starting point. The lamb skewers were bland and then came the mix-up in order. Something we didn't order was served up and we were nice enough not to argue about it. Then came the dumplings: we order a couple varieties and some of the them tasted funny....it is taste like...well, dish detergent. We asked the hostess to check it out and was told, as-matter-of-fact as she could be, since we ate half of the plate, she would charge us for the half the price for the dish. I understand one shouldn't expect much service from a restaurant located at the touristy spot, but this was in a league of its own. 

Will not go back.
author: Pascal C.

description:
At noon on Monday, I was the only person for lunch.  When I finished at 12:30 pm, every table was full. I had the xiao long bao - every dumpling was filled with steaming hot broth and the meat filling had good flavor.  The skins were not thin, but not thick; I am not complaining - they were delicious.
8 for $7.95.  Service was friendly and efficient.
author: Geri S.

description: They charge 4 dollars for green tea I think it should be free the beef noodle is good but the waitress ignored us even though we were done and sitting there looking for someone to give us our check
author: Hong H.

description: Got the shrimp dumplings. Found fish bones in there. WHAT THE HELL?
author: Mimi C.

description:
Just had the hand pulled beef noodle soup.  It was quite good!  Definitely one of the better ones in the city.

Noodles were freshly made (Xian style), so they were soft and tasted like fresh fettuccine.  Portion is not very big, which works for me.  Will be back to try their dumplings and the radish pastry.
author: Paul K.

description: This unassuming little Xian-style neighborhood restaurant is clean and welcoming, and has really good vegetarian dumplings - the delicate chopped cabbage and tofu filling contrasted nicely with the doughy dumpling wrapper. Most of their dumpling offerings are pork based, and from the look on other diners' faces they were equally as good. The cabbage salad had a sesame oil and vinegar dressing that was both earthy and tangy - and I felt homesick while eating it.  I'll be going back to try the noodles, the scallion pancake, the fried buns and the red bean paste pancake!
author: A N.

description:
I'm SO happy a place like this opened a close proximity to where I live/work. 

Honestly speaking, I'm not a huge fan of most Chinese food. I find a majority of the dishes bland, overly salty, and one-dimensional. However, the two dishes I absolutely love are Xiao Long Bao and Beef Noodle Soup (with the thick, chewy noodles). Despite living near Chinatown, I hadn't been able to find any restaurant serving a decent portion of these two items (this is probably due to a fact that a majority of the restaurants are owned by Cantonese speaking immigrants from Southern Chinese provinces). Until now with the opening of House of Xian Dumpling!

The restaurant itself is small and a bit cramped, but cleaner than a majority of other Chinatown eateries, and better yet, the staff is friendly and accommodating to non-Chinese speakers (tourists, this means you!). The space is further occupied by a small stall with a staff member hand pulling noodles for the dishes in front of you. 

Food-wise, the Xiao Long Baos are not soupy enough in my opinion, but since I have a pretty high standard for XLBs (Joe's... I miss you), this wasn't surprising. 

I've had the Braised Beef Noodle Soup and Braised Tendon Noodle Soup, both good, filling, and SPICY. My favorite dish however, is the Pork Knuckle Noodle Soup with the hand-pulled flat noodle. I love Pork Knuckle and I was delighted to find a place east of Inner Richmond that actually serves a good amount of it! The noodles are the right amount of chewiness and the broth is deliciously rich. Best of all, a bowl will only set you back $6.95!

If you're coming alone, bring cash because there is a credit card minimum of $10.
author: Sophia V.

description:
4.5 stars. My new favorite place for lunch. This place always gets packed. 

I love their handmade pulled noodles. 

The porkchop noodle soup is light, but flavorful

The chicken chow mein, get it with hand pulled noodles, it is delicious. So much flavor and the chicken is tender. 

The green onion pancake is crispy. 

XLB flavor isn't bad, but the skin is too thick for me still. 

Love this place!
author: Karen H.

description: My girlfriend and I had a great experience first time in the restaurant.  The regular pulled noodles were chewy and succulent.  As a result, we decide to come back the very next day.  However, we had a different experience the second time.  We ordered the same regular noodles but it came out with flat noodles.  The owner was arguing that they gave us the regular noodles when it fact it was bigger and wider. We had to compare it to the table next to ours.  Seriously????  How do you not know?
author: Austin Y.

description: good dumpling in financial district
author: Long C.

description:
The handmade pulled noodle was pretty good. I had the meat in gravy noodle. You can choose the type of noodle. There is a chef performing some of his noodle cutting skill in the front of the store... it is interesting to watch. 

 I was not impressed with the XLB dumpling or the pork dumpling. XLB's skin was too thick and not much soup in it.  The dumpling was super small for $6.95 for 12. We had to return our dumpling dish since it was not cook or and taste like lamb. The host returned the dish to the chef, and came  back and claim it was not lamb, and it is pork. In the end, we didn't want to reorder  any dish. WIsh i can give them a three star.
author: Theresa T.

description:
Love this place. A bright clean space with friendly and attentive management and service. Great food. Good prices. 

Love the beef noodle soup, the dumplings, the cumin lamb skewers, and the hot, sweet soy milk. 

A go-to place during the cold months of summer/any season in SF ; )
author: Sam R.

description:
My friends and I (group of 4) got: West Lake Lamb Dumplings, Chives and Shrimp Dumplings, Beef Tendon Noodle Soup, Lamb Skewers (comes as 6), and a vegetable dish (no idea the name.) Total came down to $44 (including tip/tax), and the meal could easily have served 5 instead of 4.

12 dumplings for $7 is really good! Service was good too: everything came fairly quickly and it wasn't hard at all to get the waitress's attention and ask for the bill. We went in around 6PM and there was only one other group.

The place and the tables are a bit small and feel cramped, but it's not a big deal.

The dumplings were good, very fresh. The noodle soup was also good, although the broth was a little too salty for my taste. Each dish is too large to eat alone. All-in-all a solid location that I'd consider coming back to.

Note: I don't think this place sells potstickers, only boiled dumplings. Also note: I'm half Chinese and was raised on my Chinese mom's cooking, so I have Chinese tastes.
author: Leah D.

description:
House of Xian Dumpling is a quick and easy place to have a great meal. My favorite part about House of Xian Dumpling is the fact they make their own noodles from scratch. The noodles really add unique texture and are absolutely delicious.
The beef tendon soup (spicy) is my favorite choice along with pork dumplings, in a chile sauce. The portions are great and I am always very satisfied after this meal. 
The staff is great and House of Xian Dumpling is a great place to enjoy a quick, low cost meal!!
author: Dominic P.

description: I cannot believe how bad this place is. The service was terrible as we waited for a long time and no one attended us. Then when we ordered the food is nothing close to authentic xian food. The worst part is that they imposed 18 percent tip on us after they heard us complaining about the food and they charged us the dish they did not even serve. Now it is one hour after this terrible experience and we felt so bad by choosing this place and we were so ungratified that we had to choose a second restaurant. It IS THE WORST CHINESE RESTAURANT I HAVE HAD. Very bad for the reputation of the Chinese restaurant in San Francisco!
author: Gady J.

description:
Great place for soups.

I go here on my lunch breaks at least once a week because I'm a huge fan of the dumpling soups and hand pulled noodles which they make right there in full view of the restaurant. You really can't beat a great bowl of soup for under $8, the service is fine, friendly waitresses, clean and well kept tables.  It's a popular restaurant in a small space so it can be a bit cramped in there, i have never had problem grabbing a table for one at any time, they turn them quickly, highly recommended.
author: James D.

description: Beef soup and wontons were just ok......was gonna give 3 stars, but there were too many flies.  Place doesn't look very clean.
author: Sam M.

description: Had the spicy braised beef noodles and they were great - it was a lot of food to-go as well. Couldn't finish the entire thing for lunch.
author: Deepan M.

description:
Pretty good. 3.5 stars,  but not 4.

The dumplings came out super tiny (12 for $7), so the ratio of dough to meat was off. Too much dough, and too little meat. The pork and chive was better than pork and cabbage. Chinese broccoli ($6) was cooked pretty well.

We were still hungry so we ordered the hand pulled (flat) beef noodle soup, and that was surprisingly delicious!
author: Jeanne C.

description:
LONG VERSION (Skip to SHORT VERSION below if you're impatient):  

I have been having the day from hell, or, more appropriately, the week from hell.  (Props to Richard Lewis.)  Today at noon, I needed a walk, and my partner in cryme had a conference call.  I have had a hankering for Chinese as of late, so I decided to walk approximately nine blocks to get take-out from House of Nanking. By the way, I had ripped a huge hole in the back of my pantyhose that I did not notice until about 3:00 p.m. this afternoon.  FYI, a big ass hole in the back of your pantyhose does not work well with a 1940's navy blue floral dress and brown cowboy boots. "Crackwhore" never works with vintage. 

After a 10-15 minute walk, I get in a rather long line that has formed outside of the door.  I pull out a book I've been engrossed in and start reading while I wait.  I'm standing behind four young republicans.  Ugh.  Ten minutes passed.  Now, granted, I could probably have walked into the restaurant and told the server I wanted take-out, but to be perfectly honest, I was in no hurry to get back to the office.  The server finally comes outside after about 15 minutes and asks the cabinet of young republicans how many are in their party.  Then she asks me how many are in my party, and I tell her I want take-out.  The republicans have turned around to face me now.  I'm starting to feel uncomfortable with all eyez on me.  She walks out of the front door, stands next to me, and asks me what I want.  In my most matter-of-fact tone, I tell her I would like sesame chicken with steamed rice and steamed pork dumplings.  I bet that would have been the bomb.  Ugh. Here's where things really devolve.   

She's like, "We don't have that, you have to go next door."  I'm confused, so I ask her if she's sure they don't have that.  Naturally, I had checked the menu online beforehand so I would know what I want.  The republicans are staring at me as though I just told the server I had leprosy.  She hands me a menu with the same look my mom gives me when I tell her who I'm dating.  At this point, I'm extremely uncomfortable, and I'm also glad I wore clinical strength deodorant.  For a brief moment, I thought, what if I just broke into a really fast jog and ran out of here like Lola (or "Forrest Gump-ed" my way out of it, as my sister called it).  This method has worked successfully for me in the past, when I've accidentally set off the fire alarm in a certain bar that will remain nameless.

Anyway,  I hurriedly order pork dumplings, and a side of rice with spicy chicken over it.  Here's the worst part: at that point, it still did not occur to me that I was not at House of Nanking.  Ugh.  There I was, just standing there with my teeth in my mouth, like a prize asshole.  

Finally, when the server handed me my order, I began to realize I was at the wrong place.  Don't ask me why, but I started to think about her comment that I should go next door.  Then, with the reaction I should have had about 15 minutes earlier, I looked at the place next door.  Ignorance is bliss, isn't it?  While she ran my ATM card, I felt that lovely burn of sheer embarrassment coarse through my veins.  Ugh.  She came back with the credit card slip.  I left a tip that I hoped would make me feel better about what I had just done, and she told me that I was "very generous."  UGH.  I'm on a self-imposed timeout.   

SHORT VERSION:

Well, the pork dumplings were pretty decent, although the color of the meat was a bit too pink for my taste. They were pretty standard, overall, but not remarkable.  The chicken was okay too, for a place that does not make chicken over rice as a general rule.  It was a huge portion.  

And the humble pie was delicious.
author: Sunny S.

description:
Need: Tackled my battles its been a long day. Im Hungry, and ready to throw down $$ for good food (not pub food) in the No Beach/Chinatown area, casual n walk-in friendly for 1.

Action: Skimmed yelp options in the Broadway/Columbus area. Not drunk enuf for pizza n burgers, not dressed cute enuf for italian, and too weathered for the rough service at chinese cafe joints - house of dumplings sounded like a good bet, and made from scratch was sure gonna be a better treat than the usual TJoes fare I make myself at home. 

Result: Walked in 8pm during their peak busy 85% full, and was greeted nicely (even if I was table for 1) didnt wait too long for a table. Menu balanced selection of choices, hot appetizers, cold apps, dim sum, noodle soups, and of course dumplings! with many filling options.

Ive dined 2x here in 3 weeks!  Spicy beef noodle soup, beef pancake, pork shrimp dumplings. Food quality is fresh, consistent and clean preparation. Culinary style (shanghainese?) no frills, simple, not overcooked, overseasoned, or oversauced. Ample portion size. Service friendly, hospitable, and courteous. Same aunty lady (owner?) greets and hosts all customers like guests in her home. Accomodating to table for 1 and small family groups.

Note: Would be fun to bring few friends and make a meal out of the variety hot appetizers, dim  sum, and dumplings. Or be like me and order a big bowl of hot soup to slurp it all to urself! 

See u again! Thank u xiexie!
author: Jayne S.

description: Its a convenient and clean place to try some chinese dumplings when wondering in downtown SF. Service is quick.
author: Nan J.

description: Small restaurant just border line of chinatown, financial district and north beach. Unfortunately food is anything but spectacular. Food was very mediocre. We ordered the beef noodle soup and pork knuckle soup, broth was bland, lacked flavor. Handmade noodles were nice, they were al dente. The shanghai dumplings was just ok. Some of them broke, which resulted in no soup inside. There was only 1 waitress early evening on a Friday, restaurant was almost half full, expect to wait.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Food was fine (the chive, pork, and shrimp dumpling was a standout), price was reasonable for SF, but the service was atrocious.

Was there with a buddy for lunch, and while we were finishing up, the server just started cleaning up our table while we still had food on our plate. she started by taking my chopsticks and was just going to take away my plate with food still on it! I took the plate back and said I was still eating. She just resumed cleaning and I had no choice but to just suck my dumpling off the plate! 

The food isn't bad but it's not special enough to warrant having to deal with the apathetic service, even by "Chinatown service standards."
author: Willy W.

description:
The noodle soup is among the best I've had in the city.  The only other restaurant I will rave about is in Seattle called Samuri Noodles...they are 5 stars.  I only gave them 2 stars due to one dish but this one dish was enough to ruin the meal.

The onion pancake was crispy and not greasy.   Most restaurants cook it will alot of oil and it shows on the plate.  Not this place...nice and crispy.  Another pancake worth its carb level is the chive pancake.   Its like a curry puff but filled with chive and scrambled egg.  Again, nicely cooked and not greasy.

The dish that ruined the meal is the pork knuckle.   It was extremely salty and cold...so salty we had to send it back.  I was afriad all they would do was rinse it in hot water so I had them leave the original order until the new oeder arrived...then I let them take it.  My suspension was correct.  It was hot this time and it was rinsed in hot water.  The favor was weaker and it was hot.   The inside qas still salty.

Million dollar question...will I go back.  Yes but only as last choice and once in a blue moon.
author: MickYee M.

description:
Still great. Xiaolongbao is super hot, juicy. What I like about this place in SF is that unlike some other Chinese restaurants in town, I know for certain that this place is clean, that certain dishes' elements, like the pig knuckle soup (amazing, clean flavor, with marrow pieces!) is thoroughly cleaned. Again, I'm partial because my aunt (not blood relative) runs the place. Not only has she put her heart and soul into this, but she also has an extensive background in hospitality management. How many restaurant owners can claim that? And no, she has no idea I'm writing this. Tehe.

The cooking here is not flashy. The flavors are meant to evoke homecooking, and if you notice, their soups are neither oily nor over-salted.

Try the flat-looking red bean pastry dessert! It's their own creation and it's yummy. Oh and the lamb skewers!!!! Omg, so tender. Oh and they also make their soy bean milk fresh and in house. Not sure if that's always on the menu....
author: Eda C.

description:
Worse service ever.
It took an hour for first appetizer, and it took another hour still could not complete all of our orders.
We gave up in the end.
author: Wesley C.

description:
I saw a chef making the dumplings from outside. And there's Dumpling in the name. I thought the dumplings must be good. I was wrong, terrible wrong. Our pork and shrimp dumplings came out NOT FULLY COOKED. What kind of restaurant will serve half rare pork to your customers?

After the dumplings went back to the kitchen for another hot bath, we had our dumplings again. The taste was OK. You can say it's the better dumpling in this side of the city, but definitely not as good as Kingdom of Dumplings. 

The other dishes we ordered were better than the dumplings. If they didn't put dumplings in the name, I'd give 3 stars for this review.
author: V L.

description:
I don't come to San Francisco often, especially Chinatown.  This place was a very good spot for dumplings.  I highly recommend their chive and pork dumplings!  Very chewy and flavorful.

My main complaint about this place is the seating area, it is extremely cramped.   The shrimp fried rice is very very filling.  I found the prices to be very reasonable for the food and portions we received.  I, however, did not appreciate the mandatory 18% gratuity that was applied INDIVIDUALLY.  So EACH person paid 18%...makes no sense.  

I'll probably still be coming back to try their skewers, which by the way were ALL OUT apparently, though they kept coming out.   Also, the 15$ minimum for credit card is ridiculous!   Service was decent.  4 stars for the food, minus one star for the minor annoyances.
author: Ray S.

description: Incredibly rude service, and the food isnt good at all. I ordered steamed buns, they charged me for them, and then gave me dumplings and told me they never ever have buns. The whole time she was looking on her iPhone too. Stay away.
author: Sam A.

description:
Came here for my first Chinese restaurant experience in SF since my hotel was just down the block. 
Ordered the:
Soup dumplings - incredibly mediocre....I didn't even finish it all bc the meat inside was very factory-esq (and I always finish my soup dumplings...but maybe I'm too critical bc I'm from NYC and they have some amazing soup dumplings) 
Spicy chx soup - great broth with hand pulled noodles. Huge pieces of chx. 
Lamb skewers - bleh. I thought they could have used more spice and been cooked a little more to produce that almost crunchy texture u get when u are back in china getting these skewers from outside cart vendors 
Pork dumplings in chili sauce - mediocre, the skin of the dumplings was too thick and too much for the contents inside 

On a more positive note, they are open until late if you need your chinese food fix. Also great customer service.
author: M C.

description:
Best dumpling place in SF and I spent 1 year in Beijing.
They do take-out which is always good to have.
author: Paul H.

description:
Big disappointment. Mostly because nothing we ordered had much flavor!  Very bland,
We had the chive pancake which was pretty good if you dipped it in some of the hot sauce at the table.  The soup dumplings  had no liquid inside. So dry.  Ugh

We had the pork and cabbage steamed dumplings which also had no flavor.

The salt and pepper fish was okay, not spicy or flavorful

The service was super difficult to get their attention.   There were at least five people working and they all had their backs to us and we sometimes had to wave at cook in back so he would tell waitress to go wait on the customers!
author: Foodlover B.

description: Fantastic authentic noodles and dumplings. Very very  good. Highly recommended. As good as anything I've had elsewhere in the US, if not the best.
author: Kaicheng L.

description:
YES. Dumplings. Soup. Hand-pulled noodles. Sorry; did I mention the dumplings yet? This place is next door to another restaurant that gets lots of queues and heavy traffic, so gets overlooked. But oh man- 

The potstickers and dumplings alone are amazing. The beef pancakes are epic and the spring rolls are lovely. Then, there's the soups. The noodles are hand pulled- and you can absolutely tell the difference. I'll never go back. I got the dumpling soup, with beef and radish dumplings. Didn't take a photo because I was too busy tucking in! 

Note: the soups are huge -- probably best to share unless you're absolutely starving and haven't loaded up on dumpling starters! 

The only small downsides were the service and that the owner will whisk away plates you aren't finished with unless you keep a close eye on them when a server is around. the owner was bustling around taking orders, clearing up and handling payments, and seemed to only have one other staff member on to help. So it took a while to get our order  in, and then for it to arrive. But it was so so worth it. Come here!! 

For three entrées, two giant soups and lots of green tea, the bill came to just about $40 flat. So maybe not the cheapest, but would you want to sacrifice quality for small savings?
author: Em K.

description:
Tried to get a sit down order, the waitress took three other tables order before us even though we arrived first. I asked them if they could make it Togo since we had waited 10 minutes and she never answered. So we left. 
Don't come here, very rude, poor service
author: Michael L.

description: This was the worst meal we've had in America. My family and I stopped by hoping to have an authentic heartwarming dumpling soup but instead was confronted with pretty sure Store bought noodles. The dough of the noodles and dumplings were dense and not chewy and the fillings were probably mixed using a machine. The waitress got 2 of our dishes wrong and tried to charge us for them at the end. They waitresses were very nice tho - but that doesn't compensate for the really really disappointing food.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
First time we came here, we sat for 15 minutes before a waitress approached us. Only to find out that most of the dumplings on their menu were not available.  We walked out. 

Decided to give this place one more try. We came in at 11:45.  We found out that they had no shrimp or chicken dumplings, so we ordered the pork and cabbage dumplings, xiao long bao soup dumplings, green onion pancake, and braised beef hand cut noodle soup. 

Soup dumplings were extraordinarily good!   The noodle soup had a great broth, and the noodles had a wonderful texture.  

The pork dumplings were okay, but I might be biased because I don't love the doughy Beijing-style dumplings. 

Pass on the greasy green onion pancake!

It is interesting to watch the noodle maker. He (wearing a doctor's face mask) is encased in a plastic box near the entrance of the kitchen, and is rolling out and cutting the noodles.  (Though I would have positioned him closer to the window facing the street.)

Bottom line --  Service needs to be improved tremendously. With that being said, IF you get there early, IF you have a moderate amount of patience, and IF they have most of their menu available, you should have a good meal. 

Tip to management  - I appreciate your efforts for handmade and fresh items, but consider having a blackboard that lists your available dumplings. It's not fair to your staff or your customers to have to play this guessing game of what might be available.
author: Jennifer I.

description:
I have walked by this restaurant many times thinking to myself, "I have to try this out next time."

Well, next time finally came around, and I finally visited this restaurant. It did not disappoint! I ordered lamb skewers, dumplings and got a dumpling noodle soup. Mm mm good.

The food was tasty and clean. It might be weird to describe a food as tasting clean, but if you've been to one too many greasy Chinese restaurants, you'll know what I mean. 

A solid 5 stars.
author: Richard S.

description:
Wait, there's a dumpling place in Chinatown? Where...have...I...been? 

Well, the blink-and-you'll-miss-it restaurant is right next to House of Nanking. I will usually always pick dumplings and northern Chinese fare over any other type of Chinese food, so my coworkers and I decided to try this, and got the last 4-person table at 11:45am. 

This is your typical dumpling/noodle house, with your typical Chinese resto service. Don't expect much and you'll walk away full and happy. Everything we ordered were delicious! The Xiao Long Bao was juicy and one of the better ones I've had (thumbs up!). Onion Pancakes are always a crowd-pleaser, especially when they're pipping hot. The Beef Tendon Noodle Soup was flavorful, rich, with freshly hand-pulled noodles that you can taste. House Fried Rice was the finisher, with combination of different meats and veggies, what's not to love? 

Come early. This place is tiny and fills up FAST. Be late and get ready to wait.

They take credit cards, so order to your heart's content. 

I can't wait to go back!
author: Jing D.

description:
I'm a transplant from Monterey Park and I can say this place is spot on. I've been missing the cheap and authentic eats of SoCal and this place has become a regular lunch time spot.

What we usually order ...
1. Beef noodle soup - Noodles are perfectly al dente and freshly made by hand. Broth is spicy and flavorful.
2. XLB - great if you don't want to drive all the way to outer Richmond for Shanghai dumpling king. Sadly, I have to admit that my roommate and I like to keep to a 2 mi radius of soma so this is perfect.
3. Pork and choice dumplings

While I would like to selfishly keep this local gem to myself, I thought it might be nice to give it the rating it deserves.
author: steph l.

description: Just don't go. Foods not great, and they charged 18% service fee without telling you or giving receipts, which means the "pre-tip amount" is a fraud. Bad service.
author: RJ Z.

description:
Small restaurant and easy to miss but one of the few places that has Xiao Long Bao in chinatown.  There is even a man hand pulling noodles in a glass window.

Recommend - so MANY dumplings to choose from, we ordered Xiao Long Bao, steamed chicken and corn, shrimp and chives (delicious), and dumplings in chili oil.  Dumplings were ok but love the variety. Although the braised beef noodle soup was really tasty!

Fast service during lunch time.
author: Yolanda G.

description:
I had the braised beef noodle soup with hand-pulled noodles. It was delicious! My parents are from Xi'An and I had been craving homemade food for awhile. This hit the spot. The noodles are a great consistency and the beef was super tender. I wish the broth had been a bit more flavorful because it was a little bit watery. Anyway, I will probably be back here. The food is authentic and this restaurant makes me feel at home. Service was fast and efficient (and friendlier than at most Chinese restaurants). 

Also, it was basically the only place open at 8:30PM on a Sunday night.
author: Anna N.

description:
This place certainly deserves more stars! I ordered Shanghai soup dumplings, Braised Beef noodle soup and the cold dish spicy beef tendon.

All of the noodles for noodle soup is hand-pulled, freshly made to order. You have to come at lunch to get the flat (wide) noodle, though.

Xiao Long bao is good but the filling can have some more flavor.

The spicy beef tendon is very well cooked and if you want a combo of
braised beef / tendon noodle soup, you can order a side of spicy beef tendon and the beef noodle soup and put the beef tendon into your noodle! Its a great combo that you have to try!!

Service- The server here is very attentive and nice, unlike other chinese restaurant where you do not get this kind of great service...
author: Melody T.

description:
the worst service in the world!
I waited for an hour and a half and no food is coming. If you wanna go, you'd better think twice! Only if u have so much time to waste! I hate this place
author: Sophia Z.

description: Love this place! Especially Anna, she's the best and so sweet! :) I go here all the time for lunch/dinner with my husband. I always get the soup dumplings, pork shrimp and chive dumplings, beef pancakes, and the shredded potato. Great prices!
author: Jessica B.

description: I ordered 20mins ago. Came back. The order is not ready yet. She forgot to tell the cook. Food is good
author: Eboy E.

description:
During our short trip to San Francisco, I knew I needed some authentic Chinese food and House of Xian Dumpling 100% completely satisfied my craving. 

Braised Beef Noodles - Highly recommend, much better than everything else I've tried back in DC.  Great pull and texture on the noodles, good heat from the broth, plenty of beef, although fatty that is a given.   

Pork and Chive Dumplings - Big portion!  12 dumplings to 1 order 
Soup Dumplings - Much smaller sized dumplings than I'm used to (compared to those from NYC), but still very tasty with the vinegar sauce 

Fried Rice - Not sure why this fried rice was the best homemade rice I've ever ordered, but it was very flavorful and huge portion  

Grilled Lamb Skewers - Not my favorite and thought it was more on the bland side, but the fiancé liked it a lot

At we were walking to the restaurant, I could see a long line and was afraid it was for House of Xian Dumpling and we would be waiting forever.  But the line was for the restaurant next door.  Honestly, I was a little upset, thinking that is where we should be having dinner obviously and expecting House of Xian to be a disappointment.  To my surprise, everything was so delicious and pretty cheap, our bill for 4 dishes, 1 appetizers and 1 soda was less than $40!  I wished I lived in SF so I could come back again and again and won't have to wait in line for an hour either.
author: Jenny S.

description:
What a find! Finally, a place that serves Yang Rou Chuan (Lamb Skewers with Cumin and spices!

This place serves Northern (ish) Chinese food. They also serve Xiao Long Bao (Shanghai soup dumplings- technically "southern China")

Overall, decent fare. Good selection of noodle soup, dumplings, and other northern fare (Green onion pancake, etc.)

On this meal had:

1. Braised beef noodle soup (beef broth was good, hand-pulled noodles were great, not overly chewy, beef was ok)
2. Pork and cabbage dumplings (big dumplings, decent)
3. Beef pancake (crunchy but a bit bland)
4. Lamb skewers (not as good as you can get in China, but ok)
5. Chicken skewers (meh)
6. Xiao long bao (decent)
7. Pea sprouts (tasty, though not overly flavored)

Overall, a thumb's up for the area. You can probably find restaurants that do better dishes (i.e. there are a bunch of xiao long bao places in SF and the Bay Area), but for the selection, price, location, and quality of the overall sampling of the menu. Everything we got was under $10, and you can easily order a noodle soup for $7 and be full.

Tables were a bit cramped in the middle, and it was full up during lunch hour (not a large space), but we got served quickly. Cheap, good food. No complaints on table service. Dumplings do take a while to cook. They came last in our meal.

On the next meal here, will stick with dumplings and soup. And maybe try some of the other appetizers.
author: Kiki J.

description: Really really good food! Fast and efficient service! The only bad thing I can say was they added 18% tip onto the bill even though there was only 3 of us.
author: Dayle J.

description: Food was fine, very basic. Kind of doughy. Overpriced and customer service was pretty terrible. They over charged me and then took the liberty of keeping the change! Probably will not go back.
author: Sasha B.

description:
I came last week meeting a friend here for lunch.  For me, I ordered the hot braised stew noodel soup.  The staff asked me how spicy I wanted it and I asked for medium since it was my first time here.  Turns out at that level there was to me almost no spiciness at all and I had to add hot sauce.  So now I know I have to ask for spicy if I come and order that again next time.  The beef was good, different texture from what I would normally expect.  It was served more like thick slices rather than "chunks" like that of most restaurant's beef stew.  I also enjoyed the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) that we ordered.

I would love to come back one day for dinner and try having dinner where I order the XLB and also try their hot and sour soup.
author: H K.

description:
I am very surprised that this restaurant has such a low rating! I was quite impressed with the food here when I went with my parents. 

Their noodles are fresh and hand-pulled. You can see the cook pulling them right in front of you! It is quite refreshing to go to a Chinese restaurant and know that their food is fresh. I ordered their beef noodle soup, and thoroughly enjoyed it. The broth was light and tasty (not drowning in MSG) and the noodles were oh-so-wonderful. We ordered the XLB and pork&cabbage dumplings. Both were satisfactory, but not amazing. As an appetizer, we decided on the honey chili tofu. The tofu was crisp and extremely tasty! The honey chili was amazing. We also ordered their beef pancake, but you should skip on this. The pancake should have been crisp and crunchy, but instead was soggy and bland.

Altogether, a solid experience. Note - I did come here after popular lunch hours (3 pm) so it wasn't too busy and we got wonderful service from them)
author: Hannah L.

description: I went to lunch with my co-worker and was very disappointed and about this place. It is not hand made noodle at all. Also the dumplings are  not fresh at all.
author: Nanshan L.

description:
Cute Chinese restaurant in Chinatown SF that serves XLB during non-dimsum hours. Other great dishes include potstickers and beef tendon soup with handmade noodles. Their green onion pancake is not at the top of my list. 

The place got a little crowded after 7pm on a Friday night. Get there a little earlier!

Tip: Servers speak Mandarin.
author: Goldie L.

description: Three stars for the food. Dumplings taste like home, but they definitely need to hire more waitresses and people with better English.
author: Grizabella L.

description: Soup dumplings had very thick wrapper and no soup in them. Service was very poor. I wont be returning.
author: Lucia B.

description: The waitress' English suddenly became worse when she decided to keep extra tips for herself.  Sigh.
author: Sam W.

description:
Sufficient Chinese
We ordered the shanghai dumplings, beef noodle soup, and some cold vegetable dishes
The dumplings were a bit tasteless- not much flavor in the meat and the skin was not as chewy as they should be
This def does not replace ding tai feng for your authentic dumpling fix, but it will temporarily fill your dumpling craving
author: CJ P.

description:
The House of Xian Dumpling opened about 3 months ago and is a nice addition to the Chinatown restaurant scene.  The kitchen staff are from Xian and Beijing, so the dumplings and noodles are authentic recipes.

We ordered the cold marinated pig ears, beef tendon with pulled noodle soup and the pork, shrimp & chives dumplings.  Everything was delicious.

We also enjoyed watching the Noodle Master hand-pulling and forming the noodles.  There's no doubt that the noodles we were eating were freshly made!

The service was friendly and the prices reasonable.  We'll be back to try their other dumpling and noodle dishes!
author: Zoey W.

description: Great service, super friendly and gave me great advice on what to order. I was there for an early dinner with my neighbor - both first timers. Everything we had was freshly made and very good flavor. The lamb skews, shanghai dumplings, corn & chicken dumplings, chow Mein, and the beef pancake were delicious. My friend and I keep saying how excited we are to have a fresh dumpling restaurant in the area!  I also really enjoyed watching them make fresh noodle right in front of our table. Good price, too. My new weekly go to!
author: Louisa P.

description:
I'm actually very surprised & impressed with the quality of food at this place. Didn't expect much from it simply because of the location & how it looked from the outside, but the dumplings were beyond amazing here. It was so fresh too. & the price was a steal. I'm actually quite sad that I don't live in SF. 

If you are a fan of dumplings, this place is definitely a place you need to check out. Definite recommendation.
author: Naisa L.

description: Relatively new spot on Kearny with hand made noodles and dumplings and other Chinese food (dumplings are so good that I've never had anything else on the menu). The dumplings and dumpling noodle soup are worthy of 5 stars and the people running the restaurant are fabulous. The ambiance, perceived cleanliness and the lack of decor knocks off a star. Paying a bit more attention to the details would serve this establishment well. If you're a fan  of dumplings, this is a must try.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Just don't do it. 

First, I ordered online through BeyondMenu.com but when I went to pick up the food they had no idea what I was talking about.  Okay, things happen. I ordered, paid and decided to wait.  A few minutes later the waitress came up to me asking me to pay.  I explained that I already had, showed her the receipt and the change she gave me back.  I get it, you're busy, but when a customer says they've paid and shows you the receipt you gave them not five minutes before, act like you appreciate their business.  Nope.  Just got a side-eye and a "hurumph".  Okay...

Twenty minutes later I got my soup and although it tasted okay, it would have been nice to have more than 4 pieces of beef.  Literally, there were exactly FOUR small pieces of meat.  I counted.  Lots of broth, lots of noodles, but very little meat.  Okay....

I was going to  leave it at that, but I had a lot of leftover broth and noodles so I thought I'd go back later and get more beef.  I told her that I wanted just the beef tendon, no soup, no broth.  She said okay, charged me the same price as the full soup, okay, no problem.  Then proceeded to hand me a nearly empty container with FOUR pieces of beef.  Yes, I paid the same amount to get even less than I got before.  Just the FOUR pieces of beef, no soup, no noodles.  It's my fault for thinking that I would actually get something different.  Again, the same bad customer service.  Okay....now I'm done with giving them chances.  Just don't do it.
author: Saydeah H.

description:
Get. The. Dumplings. The name is House of ....Dumplings. NOT House of Chicken Chow Mein. Capisci?

There is a guy making fresh dumpling dough in a glass dumpling booth. Get dumplings!

We ate the lamb dumplings (fabulous), the salt and pepper tofu (OK), the green chive pancake (delicious) and the red bean pancake (dessert - fabulous).

Service can be slow. You hate that? Go away and leave a table open for us.
author: Vena V.

description: If the menu items we tried (Soup Dumplings, Green Onion Fried Pancake, and Dumpling Soup w/Hand-Pulled Noodles) are representative of the quality in general, this place is a true gem. Not too bad a wait for a table on Sunday afternoon, friendly attentive service, delicious fresh dumplings and noodles, light soup broth with fresh bok choy...and we stuffed ourselves for a total of $25 including the tip for two people. Couldn't have been happier with the choice. We had some great take-out only Cantonese dim sum at a different place the day before, but Shanghai-style soup dumplings aren't necessarily on those menus, and they're best served fresh in the steamer basket to your table. Bite a hole in the top, pour in a little of the special sauce, and then you ascend to the Juicy Dumpling Heaven. Will definitely be back to House of Xian next time I'm anywhere near Chinatown or North Beach.
author: Emily F.

description: As a huge fun of Xiao Long Bao's (Shanghainese Dumplings), House of Xian definitely hits the spot. The other Shanghainese restaurants I've been to in the Bay Area pales in comparison to this newly opened restaurant. Affordable dishes on the menu too and they're open 7 days a week! Definitely order the Shanghai Soup Dumplings, Pan Friend Pork Buns, and the Beef Noodle Soup.
author: Ryan D.

description: This little spot has a tiny white sign out front that you can barely notice next to the huge house of nanking sign. Would never have seen it if my coworker didn't tell me about it. So cut to the chase. Best hand pulled noodles I've had yet. The noodles were nice and chewy. Of course there are some people who like soft pasty noodles (like the folks with no teeth) , so chewy noodles may not appeal to everyone. The menu lists beef and beef tendon noodle soup, but you can get a combo for the same price. Beef was tender and tasty. Tendon was soft but still a bit chewy. Also ordered the xiao long bao (soup dumplings) which were not so great. Wasn't terrible, since the soup was tasty, but the meat was a little not dense enough and the skin was too soft. There's lots of other little appetizers that I'm going to try at another time but for now I highly recommend the beef / tendon noodle soup.
author: m k.

description: Fantastic. Great hidden gem of a restaurant right off the strip in North Beach. Delicious dumplings and usual offerings to suit the timid, and things like pig ear and knuckle for the adventurous. Bring a big appetite, and a few bucks. This place is not expensive, and service is better than average. But it fills up during rush hours, so I recommend squeezing in during the in-betweens. If not, it's still worth the wait.
author: Gary B.

description: I love beef noodle here, and pork ones. This place gave me a great experience in San Francisco. And it's inexpensive. I tried fried rice also, however, I still love noodles here.
author: Peter W.

description: I really enjoyed this place. The quality and authenticity of wonton dumplings they prepare daily and on the hour was appreciated, and delicious! I had the pleasure of being sat down in front of the small station where a chef prepares and rolls, fresh wonton dumplings. It was to my surprise that I would even have the luxury of watching this action as I waited for my food. I ordered the boiled cabbage and pork dumpling soup, it was delicious and simple. Soup was fresh and very authentic to the Chinese culture/cuisine. Also, price was super cheap!! Only paid 6 bucks for a big ol' bowl of soup, generous portion size. The service was decent, I really can't complain, I had a nice server. Just an FYI, the restaurant is tiny, perfect for a meal for one or a small group, I wouldn't recommend bringing a big party as space is very limited.
author: Mariel C.

description: Rather a disappointment.  The beef noodle soup, as reviewed by others, was quite good but the soup dumplings and fried pork dumplings were a tasteless mush.  Skip this place is my recommendation.
author: Wayne R.

description: Be careful: They directly charge you 20% tips (or 18% after-tax), and tell you the check is "Pre-tip". I went alone, not in a big group, so it's not a service fee for 6+ppl. This is the first time that I see a restaurant explicitly writes on the check "Pre-tips" when it is not. Besides, they got me the wrong dish. Did not give 1-star because the noodles were fine.
author: Zhen L.

description:
nice staff but tourist trap food.
msg dumplings that were pastey.
home-made noodles were nice but for $2 extra is false advertising
$18 for food I barely could eat.
I should have tried next door.
okay for tourists but NOT FOR LOCALS
author: shanestar h.

description:
The service was very rude. I had a noodle and didn't bring cash. They forced me to either pay $10 for a $7 noodle with credit card or go get cash with my phone kept as a  "collateral". And the waiter said loud to another that SHE GOT NO MONEY! 

When I went back w cash to pay the waiter said: you still have to pay tips! 

Screw them!
author: Angelina Y.

description:
They get a "4" for dumplings, and a "2" for preparedness.

As many have noted, there's a gulf between what's on the menu and what's available to eat. I asked for soup dumplings. They didn't have them. I asked for shrimp and chive dumplings. They didn't have them. Ultimately, I asked what they DID have, and ate that.

I had noodle soup with pork and chive dumplings. It was delicious. The broth was light and fragrant, the noodles and dumplings were insanely fresh and flavorful. By the time I was done, there was a line out the door.

I'd suggest the owners replace the menu with a chalkboard advertising what they have. Better to notify diners, in advance, that the choices are limited -- but good. And very, very fresh.
author: Carl L.

description:
These guys are definitely still working out the kinks.  They are trying hard to provide  great service, but are too inexperienced and/or disorganized to deliver smoothness to go with the smile.

I think these are my favorite XLB among the cheap places in SF.  They are easily as good as Shanghai Dumpling King in the Richmond.  The wraps here are earthy and the thickness is good, so not to sticky.  Broth could be a little more seasoned, and meat as well, but nice and juicy.  ($6.50 for an order of 8 makes this place roughly 1/3 the price of Yank Sing... not quite as good either... but definitely palatable and a good value.)

Didn't try anything else, but will in the future.
author: Josh K.

description: Service is very good compared to most Asian restaurant s. Xiao long bao is very thick and not juicy. The pot sticker is good.
author: Nganie L.

description:
I went here twice this month with my boyfriend while we took a trip from the east coast to San Francisco. The first night we went, we had a really pleasant experience and I would give it a 4 or 5 out of 5. The lady in charge (30s/40s young with long hair) was multi-tasking and running around, but was friendly and attentive. She was nice and answered any questions we had.

The food: Soup dumplings, house special fried rice, beef noodle soup. 
Soup dumplings - were good, but couldn't beat Bob's in Chinatown, New York.
House special fried rice - pretty good for fried rice. The meat they put was well marinated and wasn't overrun with sauce. 
Beef noodle soup - the best thing we ordered. This beat my favorite beef noodle soup in Maryland by far. This was so good that I'm pretty sure it's ruined beef noodle soups anywhere else that I'm used to going in my local area. 

The second time we went, it was a different lady running the show. Slightly older looking with short hair. She was rude. She saw us enter and ignored us for a minute and then told us to pick any seat. She was gone for awhile when we were ready to order and we tried to get her attention, but she just waved back to us and decided to chat with her co-worker. When she did get back to us a few minutes later, she was just rude. After we got our food, she didn't come back to check on us and we even had to wave our hands to get her attention so we could pay the bill and get out. The restaurant wasn't overly busy, maybe 1 or 2 other tables had customers. We ordered similar things but swapped the soup dumplings for grilled chicken skewers only to receive chicken skewers that were clearly fried. The fried rice didn't seem as great as the first night and I had to wonder if it was a different chef. Anyway, this second experience was a 2 out 5 for me.
author: Allie O.

description: It was honestly just okay. Food could have tasted better. We got soup dumplings, vegetarian noodle soup and lamb skewers. The last one was really good. I liked the space inside and the ambiance, but I was disappointed with the food.
author: J L.

description: I don't usually write reviews but this time I had to because the server really made me upset. I ordered 1 beef noodle soup and 1 order of pork dumpling and nothing more. A few minutes later She brought a plate of peanut/sliced cucumber that I thought was complimentary because this is usually at alot of other Asian restaurants so I didn't think anything of it. She then brought out the noodle soup and dumplings which was decent and she looked at my cucumber dish and mumbled something is Chinese to herself as she walked away. After I was done she brought over the check and it showed that I got charged $5.95 for the little peanut/cucumber dish that I did not order or want. I went up to the counter and told her and she said it's not complimentary so I told her I didn't order this or wanted it and she told me you ate it so you have to pay for it. I'm standing here thinking I am getting scammed. I told her that's not right for you to bring me a dish I didn't order and say nothing about it and expect me to pay but she kept on refusing take responsibility for her mistake. She finally said I will knock off $3 half of the dish price and I was like no I shouldn't pay for your mistake and again she refused so I was like screw it I'm not spending any more time arguing with her about her mistake and I paid for the bill. If I was in her shoes no questioned asked I would not charge you for my mistake. Right after I paid she gave me my receipt and told me tip was not included and I was thinking in my head really? are you kidding me? Of course I know that. I shouldn't even tip you for the bad service you gave me but I'm a reasonable guy so I left her $2 for a $20 bill. Usually I could care less about bad service just as long as you serve me good food and charge me the correct amount but in this case I felt forced to pay for something I didn't order.. Anyways I would recommend this place for dumplings but make sure you only get what you ordered.
author: Jesse S.

description: Bad customer service ,no smile ,no recommend ,no communication.both chef and boss didn't give customer service at all.and when I asked if the fried bread come with any sauce,they were like what the hell you don't know what's fried bread,and serve said there have steam bread and fried bread.what the hell,I 'll never go there again
author: Yue Z.

description:
I felt like throwing up when I saw the 1cm roach float up after I finished the noodles. So I had to wait a few weeks to cool down before writing a more objective review.

Who am I kidding? It was still gross and reviews are subjective. I had the dumpling noodle soup, which was really good... until the very end when I spooned up the broth and a roach the size of my fingernail floated up (hidden under the noodles). I couldn't speak, so I flagged a waitress and pointed. The family next to me saw it, too, and although they looked alarmed, continued eating their noodles. The waitress quickly whisked the bowl away. I was not looking for another bowl or a free meal. At the end, she explained to me that since I ate all the noodles, they couldn't give me another bowl, but next time I come in, she'd give me extra noodles. She also said it would've been okay if I had eaten the roach because it was "good protein." She then tried to tell me it must've crawled in the back where they keep the bowls of noodles, because there were no roaches in the pot of soup (keep in mind, I was not saying very much or initiating conversation because I was still in a state of shock from seeing the ROACH in my soup). She then gave me my check for the entire meal. I paid, left, but the more I thought about it, the more upset I got about how the situation was handled. I wished I took a picture of the roach to post before she took my bowl away. I don't think I'll be coming back for "extra noodles." Oh well. What's done is done. I finished the noodles. I did not eat the roach. But it was there, hidden, the whole time WHILE I was eating.

So, although the food smelled and tasted good, rich flavors, and authentic, I cannot overlook the way this situation was handled or the cleanliness of the restaurant (since it did not seem to phase my neighboring table, it must not be unexpected). I also wonder how "fresh" the noodles are if the bowls are sitting in the back for a roach to crawl in. I thought hand pulled noodles were made to order, so there wouldn't be a chance for the roach to crawl in. And if it did, I wonder if they would even make a new bowl, since it's "good protein." If anything, the waitress might've said too much.

I do love hole in the wall restaurants, and I've eaten at some shady street corners, so the waitress was right: it's just protein, and I'll live. But when you are an established, professional hole in a wall, in the USA, you should address roach issues. I don't think I'll be coming back, but if I do, I'll be sure to stir up my food carefully before eating. I recommend you do the same.
author: Teresa P.

description: One of the best dim sum places in the city. Highly recommend the soup dumplings and beef noodle soup. The noodles are the perfect texture, you can tell they are freshly made. Any of the greens are also good.
author: Bethany D.

description: This was delicious place. I highly recommend the food. The noodles looked and tasted homemade and the dumplings were good.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
HALF HOUR WAIT FOR SOUP THAT NEVER CAME. Once upon a time, there was a lovely little Train-that-could restaurant called Chef Jia's next to the legendary House of Nanking. There could be an hour wait next door, but you could sit right down at Chef Jia's and have a terrific meal, reasonably priced, served super quick. But they must've run out of steam &  this place took over. 

Their thing is dumplings, which only come 12 to a serving. If you're on your own, it's chow mein, fried rice or soup for you. 

Should've known from the slack faced, glassy eyed demeanor of the staff that this wasn't gonna work out. 30 minutes after I ordered a bowl of dumpling soup, I walked out. 

These folks don't care & the one time I ate here before, it showed up in their food. This time, it showed up in no food to be had. Inexcusable. I mourn Chef Jia's and pray for a quick death for this place.
author: Dizz A.

description:
lots of food for 3

ordered:
-beef noodle soup: all of our fave.. hand pulled noodles had a great chew
-chinese broccoli w oyster sauce
-cucumber w peanuts
-xlb
-pork potsticker
-chive pork dumpling: weakest jiaozi
-pork shrimp dumpling
-beef skewers
-salt and pepper pork chops
-green onion pancake

in hingdsight we couldve done wo 2-3 dishes.. we had lots to take away

i'll def come back for the beef noodle soup and a few other things
author: Raquel T.

description: Not good service and average food. They don't tell you that they don't take card until you go to pay, then say if you order more they can?
author: Michael B.

description: We might have had the wrong appetite for one dish we ordered: the vegetarian potstickers heavily feature cabbage which wasn't in our plan.  The soup dumplings and the chili oil dumplings were delish, as was the green onion pancake.  This is a small place so be thankful (and fast) when you get your seat so others can partake in the goodness!
author: Lindsay A.

description: DEFINITELY RECOMMEND! This place was just what we wanted. A small little "hole in the wall" restaurant with friendly staff, cute atmosphere, and absolutely DELICIOUS food! We ordered the steamed buns, pork dumplings, and house fried rice. We were amazed at the quality of the food, so flavorful! We enjoyed it so much we ordered some house chow mein after everything, and we're not disappointed. The tea was on-point, and chopsticks and forks were given to everyone. As we were leaving, another one of the customers (a lady with a Chinese accent) remarked "Now THESE are dumplings!"-- The only thing we were bummed about? We forgot our leftovers! Not that there was much left over...... Definitely coming back here again!!
author: Morgan H.

description: Horrible service. The food is ok but far from authentic, not even remotely related with Xi'an food. Will never go again, and will never recomend to our friends.
author: Yu F.

description: This is the real deal. Shanghai style soup dumplings are delicious, freshly made and reasonably priced. Best noodles in town as well. This is not a fancy touristy place like Nanking next door but a true gem. And now they even serve beer !
author: David A.

description: HAND made NOOOODLES and hand made dumplings?!!  Hellzzz yeah!  It's a hole in the wall, so leave the caucasians at home unless they have yellow fever or like asian food.
author: christopher h.

description: The beef noodle soup was good. The dumplings was decent but underfiiled. The xao long bao wasn't freshly made, almost taste like frozen supermarket ones. The mandatory 18% tips was a turn off.
author: Malnik M.

description: Food is decent, service is terrible. Be aware of the "service fee" on your check. They won't care if you tip or not because they will charge it with your meal. After bringing us the check the waitress began cleaning the table, she took our cups away while I was still trying to drink, so they could rush us to pay and leave, that's just rude. So when I look at the check she charged us 18% "service fee/tip" on top of the food and tax, we were only 4 people. 18% service fee For What?! I mean I noticed some places do that because lots tourists don't tip do to their culture; so they included it with the bill, but we are not international tourist, and I was going to tip, now consider how we were treated, it aint worth 18%, she doesnt deserve it. It just bothers me that they don't do it to everybody but only to customers that speak foreign languages or look foreign. I'm giving them one star because the way they judge and criticize people not  because of the food.
author: Tao W.

description: we were guided by the Lonely Planet to try the House if Nanking. but the super long waiting line outside at a chill made us step into this restaurant. But it was so good and nice. We four people had noodle, steamed buns, dumplings and also vegetables. The price is so good. and the owner there is always smiling to us. The owner even tried to stop us from ordering too much food. We all just had a good dinner. We even wish to go back again. but what a pity we just stayed in SF for one night. We highly recommend u to order the shanghai steamed buns.
author: Monica X.

description:
Had a dinner with coworkers after work yesterday as it's new and close to where we work. We went there to give it a try but it didn't impress me.

The place is small with couples of tables that didn't make me feel comfortable to sit there. We ordered the appetizers, dumplings and noodles. They looked ordinary and could not trigger my appetite. The taste was bland and barely surprised or impressed me. The tea was so diluted that it was just better than plain water. The only good thing was that the staff were nice and friendly.

I think it is a to-go place better than a dine-in restaurant since the place is small. Will consider to order to-go there for a quick lunch during a busy working day.
author: Yvonne S.

description:
In short, DON'T COME!

I was a bit excited to try a new spot that serves dumplings and handmade noodles. I arrived during the lunch hour and waited about 30 minutes. The wait should've been shorter because as I saw customers leave, none of the tables were being cleaned up to allow for new customers to be seated. What was shocking was that they had a table that they allowed this one customer to sit there while she waited for her to-go order! That table could've and should've been used for dine-in customers!

When we were seated, we ordered immediately. Here's where I knew there was something utterly wrong with this place. We ordered the XLB (the first item on their menu). The waitress said they don't have them. What?! The number one thing you have on your menu...the item that your restaurant is named for...and you don't have them!? Ok, we ordered the chive and pork boiled dumplings. Waitress says they don't have chives. WTF! How can you not have these basic menu items?! We ended up trying the beef noodle soup, pot stickers, and cabbage/pork dumplings. 

What I didn't understand was that there were 4 tables that needed to be cleaned, and there was a line of customers outside. No one was cleaning that tables! There were 8 workers (between servers and cooks) and only 12 tables! 

20 minutes later, we got our noodle soup. Not bad. Not the best, but ok. 20 minutes later we got our boiled dumplings. They came out hot, and again, not bad. By now, I'm wondering where those potstickers were. The waitress came by and asked if everything came yet. Did she really forget that she ordered potstickers for us? We had only ordered 3 things, for heavens sake.  By then, I realized that (1) they were going to start cooking our potstickers now (40 minutes into our lunch), or (2) we were going to get the most overcooked, cold potstickers ever. Well, we got our potstickers hot. They had just cooked it. We asked for our bill now, anticipating that it may take another 20 minutes to get our bill. But our lunch wasn't done just yet. As we started to eat the potstickers, we received a "hairy" surprise on the plate. We flagged the waitress and told her to take it off our bill and don't worry about giving us another order. What was quite comical was that she took it off our bill and came back and was about to give us seven dollars and change. We were confused because we didn't even pay yet and she was giving us money?!!!!  We should've just took the money and went.

Anyways, I had to try the place out and I know never to come back. If you enjoy these lunch experiences, feel free to give it a try; otherwise, I hope I saved you a trip here.
author: Rick T.

description: So I watched the guy who was making noodles sneeze right into it and keep going. Nuff said. I walked out.
author: Caleb S.

description: Amazing Xiao Long Bao / Shanghai Soup Dumpling! I'd say of the same level as Shanghai Dumpling King or Kingdom of Dumpling. Had 3 orders of it and truly enjoyed it. Very soupy, doughy outer shell that doesn't break when you pinch with chopsticks, and great flavor. Highly recommended.
author: Erin P.

description: My favorite dumplings in los angeles.  I think i tried better only in NYC Chinatown,  but looking all around LA for authentic dumplings- i think this one is a winner.  I liked pretty much everything i ordered here. Service is good and polite.  Call before coming to check approximate waiting time. One time at peak of lunch time i waited about an hour,  the other two times no wait time at all.
author: James L.

description:
i LOVED house of xian.

the service was great, the restaurant was clean and bright and i loved the dumpling maker in the middle of the dining room. 

and the food!!  that was DE-liiiicious!  i had the salt and pepper chicken wings.  they were perfectly crispy and nice and juicy.  me and my friend had 3 different kind of dumplings and they were awesome too.  all of it even tasted just as good the next day.

you can't beat the prices either; 12 chicken wings for $7 and 12 dumplings for either $7 or $8 depending on what kind you get.  i also liked the special sauce in the little tea pot.  i will most definitely be going back.
author: lori s.

description: I really enjoyed this place. The owner was so friendly. We talked during my meal making my dining a great time, service was fast. I ordered the salt and pepper fish fillet and chicken noodle soup. The only thing i'd say is  the soup needed more salt for flavor. Other than that. Great eats!
author: Michelle M.

description: Went here on the night of the Chinese New Year's parade.  We looked at yelp to search for restaurant that serve Xiao Long Bao.  We walked a while to find this place as the celebration was dwindling down.  We stood in line for about 45 minutes, as there were 3 other parties in front of us.  Couple of tables were finished eating already but they took their time playing video games on their phone not caring about the people waiting in line.  Well we finally got seated and came here for one thing - the Shanghai Soup Dumpling (Xiao Long Bao).  I looked around the restaurant and didn't see any other patrons ordering it.  We had 2 orders which took about about 10 minutes, they explained that the kitchen was backed up and the XBL took extra time.  The first order must've been standing for a bit as the soup inside wasn't really hot.  But the 2nd order came out perfect.  It was delicious and made my XBL cravings satisfied.
author: Reid I.

description: I am updating as I've been back here another couple of times and am overdue.  They have more staff and everyone is more of a groove getting you seated and your food.  I still think the to-go option is tough to manage, no place for people to hang in this cramped little spot while they are waiting.  There are times there are things not available on the menu.  But the food is a solid 4 stars and the toothy noodles are delicious!
author: Donna H.

description: Flavorful and delicious hand-pulled noodle soup (about $9). I ordered the one with beef and tendon, which you can tell was cooked for hours since the tendon tasted delicate and so soft that it almost melted in my mouth. It also added substance and seasoning to the thick beef broth, which included some chili oil flakes and a couple of bok choy sections to balance it out. Soup dumplings (about $8) came in a steamer bowl with 8 perfect mouth-sized pieces and a ginger/red-wine vinaigrette sauce. Dumpling skin was just right, not overly doughy but had enough texture to make them slightly chewy before the soup gushes into your mouth. Highly recommend this place and those two dishes. Good for smaller groups of 2-4 people (there's less of a wait) since the restaurant only has about 30 seats and about 10 tables total. I will definitely be back to try more of their specialties. They also take VS/MC credit card now with a $15 minimum.
author: Vinh T.

description: This was a surprise find--we had beef tendon noodle soup, pork and green onion steamed dumplings, and the chive pancake.  Cheap and tasty, good portion size.  We will be back!!
author: C L.

description: I came to this place this morning. We ordered 4 dishes. The old lady came talk to us said they don't have two of my order in a bad attitude seems like it is our fault order the food they don't have. The short hair hair server is really nice. Poor service!!!!
author: Xuehua C.

description: Cheap, fast and delicious.  I believe that's what you're looking for in a good restaurant?  The place was clean as well.  Food came pretty quick...... trust me when I say my eyes were bigger than my stomach - but the bill... was so little! would love to go back!
author: Minnie S.

description: Came here at around 3-ish for a late lunch. I'd the beef tendon noodle soup. Noodles & tendon were fine but I find the soup to be a little salty. Service was just horrible. The server didn't bother to clean up the tables (even though the customers have left over 10 mins ago, and I saw a table (with the customers still around) where the empty bowls & plates were all piled up at the corner of the table. When I asked for the bill, the server came with my check, and then walked away without removing the empty bowl of noodle soup from my table. She went back to spot she was earlier to chat with her coworkers. Ugh, I hate restaurants with poor service. Don't think I'll ever come back again.
author: Jun N.

description:
Just passed by and decided to go in. We ordered:
1. hot pickled mustard tuber & shredded pork noodle soup
2. boiled chives, pork, and shrimp dumplings
3. stir fried pea sprouts
4. red bean paste pancake. 

Everything was delicious EXCEPT #4 the red bean paste pancake. It's a Shanghainese dish meant to be fried, oily, and with a black paste NOT red bean. Their's was dry and just not tasty. The pork in the noodle soup was a bit dry. Other than that, the price was right, and the service was decent. Total was $26! Can't beat that.
author: Lisa F.

description: Great home away from home food! The beef noodle soup was very good, noodles are perfect texture. The dumplings are delicious, the owner is very nice and attentive.
author: Lin W.

description: The best hand-made dumplings I've ever had in the Bay Area. Will definitely come back.
author: Lilian Q.

description:
Solid 3.5 stars but rounding to 4 for nice, friendly service. Tasty beef noodle soup, green onion pancake, xiao long bao, chicken chow mein and thousand layer bun (steamed or fried). Heard the skewers are good but did not try. 
You can't really get away from the little bit greasy feeling after a chinese meal, but good reataurant if you are looking for authentic chinese food w pleasant service.
author: Alexa L.

description: They added 20% tip to our bill.  We were a party of two.  The service was sub-par.  They must have thought we were tourists.
author: E L.

description: My sister and I came here upon realizing we wouldn't have time to eat at House of Nanking next door and still make our plans afterwards. Her pork pot stickers were much better than my non-fried cabbage and chicken dumplings. In fact, they were delicious. The shredded pig ear appetizer scarred me for life. I wasn't sure what to expect, but it was like hard gelatin that was kind of musty and minty at the same time. I try to be adventurous, but my American palate can only take so much. No regrets.
author: Milhouse N.

description: Wonderful! It was a quiet evening, so service was fab. Great takes on xian classics (the boiled lamb dumplings were amazing, fresh and grassy and chewy with some cilantro. yum) and a really excellent xiao long bao. oftentimes i go for the mixed crab and pork ones, but these were straight pork and SUPER porky, in a good way! really flavorful, delicate wrappers that still had the perfect amount of chew. everything was cheap and amazing.
author: Sam R.

description:
pork and cabbage dumpling was ok
fried redbean pancake was ok
beef noodle soup was ok
lamb skewer was ok
author: Diane W.

description: Very good service here.  Had a chance to practice my cantonese.  Had the soup dumpling, beef tendon noodles, and beef and fish ball noodles.  Also added a Choy Sum with garlic as a vegetable.  The food was tasty.  Would come back again.  Parked at a nearby underground garage for $5.
author: Kevin L.

description: This spot is close to home, so it gets a bonus star.  The dumplings are delicious.  The soup dumplings are pretty dry, I prefer Yank Sing dumplings.  I think everything is handmade there, the noodles and dumplings.  It's fairly cheap too.  So it's a good go to spot when looking for something close by and quick to eat.
author: Lyly N.

description: Good hand-cut noodles and house made dumplings. There's a guy making fresh noodles in the restaurant behind a plexiglass showcase - pretty entertaining and whets your appetite!
